entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Spiritual Discipline.

classFeature.name: Reaper/Guardian
entries: Once you reach 11th level, you choose the path of the Reaper or the Guardian. Your choice grants you a feature, which is detailed below.
You can use the reaction of the feature you gain three times, regaining all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Reaper
entries: You can absorb the energy from souls to empower yourself. When a creature within 30 feet of you dies, you can use your reaction to absorb a fragment of their soul, which you can keep within you until you finish your next long rest.
Once per turn when you deal force, radiant, or necrotic damage to a creature, you can expend a soul fragment to increase the damage that creature takes by {@damage 2d10}.

entries.name: Guardian
entries: You can grant souls some of your spiritual power to protect from death. When you or a creature within 30 feet of you is reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can use your reaction to have that creature drop to 1 hit point instead.

classFeature.name: Soul Surge (two uses)
entries: At 11th level, you can use {@classFeature Soul Surge|soulshaper|ccg|3} twice between long rests.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Elevated Vision
entries: Starting at 14th level, you have an unlimited number of uses of your {@classFeature Spectral Sight|soulshaper|ccg|2} feature.

classFeature.name: Spiritual Discipline feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted by your Spiritual Discipline.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Everlasting Soul
entries: Once you reach 18th level, your pure connection to your soul causes you to age slower. For every 10 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year.

classFeature.name: Spirit Shift
entries: Also starting at 18th level, you can cast either the {@spell etherealness} or {@spell astral projection} spell once without expending a spell slot. You regain the ability to cast either spell after you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Ascendant Aspect
entries: At 20th level, your journeys have awakened another emotional aspect within you. Choose another aspect option from those provided in your {@classFeature Soul Surge|soulshaper|ccg|3} feature.

classFeature.name: Soul Surge (three uses)
entries: At 20th level, you can use {@classFeature Soul Surge|soulshaper|ccg|3} three times between long rests.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Curse
entries: Barbarians that walk the Path of the Curse harbor a malicious presence within their body, which fuels their rage. When these barbarians enter a state of fury, this curse takes control, and at this point nothing will stop them from annihilating everything around them. Some of these barbarians accept this curse as a gift, and others fight with their curse—forcing it to work in their favor.
You can choose the origin of your curse yourself or determine it by rolling on the following table.

rows: A magical hex was placed on you, which takes the form of runic marks across your body. You draw from its arcane power when you rage.
A demon is trapped within your soul, which is unleashed when you rage.
An aberrant parasite has infected your body, which you allow to take over fully when you rage.
A lycanthropic curse is buried deep within you, which awakens when you rage.

subclassFeature.name: Colossal Might
entries: Starting at 3rd level, a visceral power awakens within you, allowing raw might to drive your strikes. You gain proficiency in all improvised weapons, and while you aren't wielding a shield, you can roll a {@dice d10} in place of the normal damage for your unarmed strikes and improvised weapons, provided you make the attack roll using Strength and the attack is not made as a part of a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Unleashed Fury
entries: At 3rd level, the curse that lies within you begins to fuel your fury. When you rage, you can choose to unleash the power of your curse, going berserk for the duration of your rage.

While berserk, you must use your action each round to attack the creature closest to you, and when you do, you must use your {@classFeature Reckless Attack|barbarian||2}. If you have multiple possible targets, you attack one at random. If you can make extra attacks as a part of the attack action, you use those extra attacks. Also, you cannot use your movement to move further away from the creature closest to you, and you cannot use your bonus action to end your rage. When there are no hostile creatures within 60 feet of you that you can see or hear, this berserk state and your rage automatically ends.

While in this berserk state, you draw power from your curse, fueling your strikes. The first time you hit an attack each turn, you can impose an effect on the target based on the type of weapon used, as detailed below. If one of the following effects requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.
{@b Melee Weapon.} The target bleeds profusely from the attack. It must make a Constitution saving throw or take necrotic damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your barbarian level.

{@b Unarmed Strike.} You can immediately attempt to {@action grapple} or {@action shove} the target as a part of the attack, provided they are not too large for you to do so. If your check succeeds, you also deal {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage to the target.

{@b Improvised or Ranged Weapon.} The target is terrorized by the attack. It must make a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. The frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Ungodly Physique
entries: At 6th level, your physical prowess is unmatched. Your jump height and distance is doubled, you deal double damage to objects and structures, and you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity, the weight you can push, drag, or lift, as well the creatures you can {@action grapple} or {@action shove}.

subclassFeature.name: Brutal Strikes
entries: Also starting at 6th level, your unarmed strikes and attacks with improvised weapons count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to non magical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Strength Over All
entries: At 10th level, you can use your might in almost every situation. When you make an ability check or saving throw using an ability score other than Intelligence or Wisdom, you can add your Strength modifier to the result. You must choose to do so before the roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Strength modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodlust
entries: Starting at 14th level, you know if the hit points of a creature you can see is less than your Strength Score. When such a creature's hit points fall below this threshold or you start your turn and can see such a creature, you can use your reaction to move up to half your speed and make a single melee attack with an unarmed strike or improvised weapon against them, provided your speed would allow you to do so. If the attack hits, the creature instantly drops to 0 hit points.

subclassFeature.name: College of Momentum
entries: Bards of the College of Momentum live for music: sick beats, intense riffs, and powerful drops. These bards wield their songs as weapons, not only to entertain their fans, but to change minds.

subclassFeature.name: Increasing the Tempo
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your walking speed increases by 10 feet and your movement is unaffected by nonmagical {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. Also, you gain proficiency with all {@filter vehicles|items|source=phb;dmg|miscellaneous=mundane|type=vehicle;vehicle (land)=sor}.

entries.name: Mechanical Momentum
entries: As a bard of the College of Momentum, your increased speed may be a result of many different things—your character could ride on a magnificent mechanical hoverboard, wear magically enhanced roller skates, or simply be invigorated by the power of their own beats. If you choose to flavor this feature as a special piece of equipment, only your character should be able to use it.

subclassFeature.name: Adrenaline Rush
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, you grow more aware of when a fight is about to break out, starting your music at the perfect time. When you roll for initiative and are not {@quickref surprise||3||surprised}, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Bardic Inspiration|bard||1}, rolling the die and adding the result to your initiative roll and the initiative roll of an ally that can hear you within 30 feet of you. You can choose to use this feature after a creature makes its roll, but you can use this feature only once per combat.

subclassFeature.name: Melody of Momentum
entries: Starting at 6th level, your powerful melodies keep your allies focused on the fight and make them more agile. Creatures other than you that are affected by your {@classFeature countercharm|bard||6} have their speed increased by 10 feet. Additionally, when you use your countercharm, its range is 120 feet, and your performance lasts for 1 minute, instead of until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Beat Drop
entries: Also at 6th level, your songs begin to grow and build to climactic drops. When you use your countercharm, you can choose to also start an instrumental build up, which lasts until your countercharm ends. This build up, as well as your countercharm, ends early if your turn starts and you or any of your allies haven't attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage from a hostile creature since then.

Your build up is represented by a pool of dice, each having an equal size to your Bardic Inspiration die. Your build up pool starts with two of such dice and gains two more dice at the end of each of your turns.

When you or a friendly creature within 30 feet of you that can hear you deals damage with an attack or spell while you are in your build up, you can use your reaction to end your build up and your countercharm in a destructive drop. Roll all of the dice in your build up pool, adding it as extra thunder damage against one target of the attack or spell. When a target takes this damage, it must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your bard spell save DC or be pushed 5 feet away from the attacker for each build up die rolled and fall prone.
Once you end your build up in this way, you can't start it again until you finish a long rest, unless you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher to start it again.

subclassFeature.name: Exhilarating Beats
entries: When you reach 14th level, you master the art of musical momentum. You gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move. Creatures affected by your countercharm also share this ability. Also, when a creature rolls a Bardic Inspiration die that you granted to them, they can use their reaction to move up to half their speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Missionary Domain
entries: Clerics of the Missionary Domain operate within a variety of different orders under a diverse set of deities, but they all have been granted the same purpose—spread the word of their god. For some this mission is a virtuous act, and for others, it is simply one side of their deal for divine power. In Prismatic Falls, many of the clerics who follow this path are followers or leaders of the cults that run the city.
You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception}, {@skill Performance}, or {@skill Persuasion} skill (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Blessing of the Believer
entries: Also starting at 1st level, you can empower your allies in exchange for their faith. When an ally within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can use your reaction to give them advantage on the roll. When you do, the ally must proclaim the name of your deity or receive no benefit.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Sacred Words
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to alter the emotions of those around you.

As an action, you present your holy symbol, evoke the name of your deity and say a few words about them, choosing from one of the options below. Choose a number of creatures within 30 feet of you that can hear you, up to a number equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of one) to be affected by your chosen words for 1 minute. An unwilling creature must make a Wisdom saving throw to resist this effect. If such a creature fails, it can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
{@b They are mighty.} Affected creatures are {@condition frightened} of you for the duration.
{@b They are merciful.} Affected creatures are {@condition charmed} by you for the duration.
{@b They are fearless.} Affected creatures can't be frightened or charmed for the duration.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Missionary
entries: At 6th level, if you speak to a single humanoid or group of humanoids that are all within 60 feet, for at least 1 minute and talk about your deity, you can attempt to magically infuse them with faith. At the end of the conversation, the targets must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your cleric spell save DC or have the thought of your deity linger in their mind for 1 hour. Until then, you and allies you choose have advantage on all Charisma checks directed at those creatures. Once the effect ends, or if a creature succeeds on its saving throw against the effect, a target has no hint that you tried to magically influence it.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Holy Emissary
entries: At 17th level, you become a divine representative of your god, inspiring your allies and terrifying your enemies. You can use your {@subclassFeature Channel Divinity: Sacred Words|Cleric||Missionary|ccg|2||Sacred Words} feature as a bonus action, rather than an action. Also, at the end of each of your turns while you are using the feature, you can cause all affected creatures that can see you to either take 10 psychic damage or gain 5 temporary hit points (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Crystals
entries: Druids of the Circle of Crystals have a deep connection to arcane crystals, which are magically infused crystals discovered in the early settlement of Prismatic Falls. To these druids, naturally occurring sources of such crystals are sacred, and they believe that they harbor the closest and deepest connection to the intrinsic magic of the world.

subclassFeature.name: Diamond Skin
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your skin is covered by a sturdy layer of crystals. While you are not wearing any armor, your AC equals 12 + your Wisdom modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.
Also, you can use any of these crystals as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: At 2nd level, you have become one with crystals, such that they protrude out of your body. These crystals grant you access to some spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the table below.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Crystallize
entries: Also at 2nd level, you gain the ability to transform latent magic into arcane crystals. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|druid||2} to conjure a chunk of crystals within 30 feet of you, rather than transforming into a beast. These crystals last for 1 minute, or until you lose your concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell), at which point the crystals shatter and turn into a fine dust.
The crystals have one of the following effects, which you choose when you conjure them.

{@b Encasing Crystals.} The crystals grow out of the body of a creature within range and restrict their movement. It must make a Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, the target can repeat the saving throw, destroying the crystals and ending the effect on a success.

{@b Shielding Crystals.} The crystals grow on the body or armor of a willing creature within range, which grants them resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine for the duration.

{@b Refracting Crystals.} The crystals appear out of the ground within range as a medium sized magical object for the duration. Once per turn when you cast a spell with a range of 10 feet or more, you can cause the spell to refract through the crystals, provided they are within 30 feet of you and you can see them. If you do, the spell is cast through the crystal's space, and you can use the crystal's line of sight when casting the spell, potentially allowing you to target creatures behind corners or at an extended range. Also, you gain a {@damage 2d4} bonus to one roll of the spell, which must restore hit points or be a damage roll. If it is a damage roll for radiant damage, this bonus increases to {@dice 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Crystal Beacon
entries: At 6th level, you can use your action to detach one of your crystals, placing it within the ground to be used as a beacon. You can have a number of these beacons active at any time equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of one). If you try to place more, the oldest one you placed shatters. You can always sense the direction to each of your individual beacons, so long as you are on the same plane as them.

In addition, the {@spell channel senses|ccg} spell is always prepared for you and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. When you cast it, your beacons serve as sigils for the spell, and if you target one of your beacons, you can cast it without expending a spell slot. When you cast the spell this way, its range is unlimited.

subclassFeature.name: Resistant Gems
entries: Once you reach 10th level, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition poisoned} or {@condition stunned}. In addition, you have resistance to poison and radiant damage.

subclassFeature.name: Reflect Attack
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you are hit with an attack by a creature you can see, you can use your reaction to reflect it back to your attacker. You take no damage from the attack, then, you make a melee or ranged spell attack against the original attacker, based on the original attack. On a hit, they take the damage you would have taken, along with any additional effects that would have been inflicted by the attack.

Alternatively, when you successfully interrupt a spell that would have targeted you with {@spell counterspell}, you can change the target of the spell to the original caster instead of having the spell fail. If the spell had {@status concentration|phb}, you must then concentrate on it.
Once you use either option, you can't use this feature again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Weaponforger
entries: Fighters of the Weaponforger Archetype are specially trained in modifying weapons to unlock their full potential. Their attacks are furious, yet calculated, and are enhanced with a variety of powerful arcane bursts. Often soldiers on the front line, these versatile warriors keep an arsenal of different weapons, ready for anything they might face.

subclassFeature.name: Hot Swap
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you are adept at quickly switching between weapons, even in the heat of battle. You can draw and stow any amount of weapons on your turn, even when you would normally be able to draw and stow one.
Additionally, you gain proficiency in {@item tinker's tools|ccg} or {@item runetech tools|ccg} (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Martial Modification
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to infuse your weapons with arcane modifications that make them more powerful and alter how they function.

entries.name: Learning Weapon Mods
entries: You learn five weapon mods of your choice, which are detailed below.
You learn one additional weapon modification of your choice at 7th, 10th, and 15th level. Each time you learn a new modification, you can also replace one modification you know with a different one.

entries.name: Applying Weapon Mods
entries: When you finish a long rest, you can choose three weapons and install one of your known weapon mods to each. You must install a different modification into each weapon, and you can't install a mod into a weapon that already has a weapon mod installed. Once a weapon is modded this way, only you are considered proficient in it.

You can choose one additional weapon to install a weapon mod into at the end of a long rest once you reach 7th level, for a total of four, and one more at 15th level, for a total of five. These must abide by the above prerequisites.

entries.name: Charges
entries: Each of your modified weapons has three charges, and each regains all of their expended charges when you finish a long rest. When you make a weapon attack with one of your modified weapons, you can activate that mod by expending one of the weapon's charges, applying all of the following effects for that attack only. You must choose to do so before you make the attack roll.

items: The weapon attack deals an extra 2d8 damage on a hit.
The damage type of the weapon changes to the damage type indicated in the weapon mod's description.
And an additional effect, which is specified in the weapon mod's description.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: Some of your weapon mods require a target to make a saving throw to resist the mod's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

subclassFeature.name: Weapon Mods
entries: Weapon mods come in a variety of shapes and sizes, but at their core, they are magitech augments that attach to weapons. A weapon mod might involve canisters of mana, crystal shards, mystical runes, or elements made of pure magic. The mods are presented in alphabetical order.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Weapon Mod
entries: At 7th level, you learn an additional weapon mod of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Artisan
entries: At 7th level, you learn the {@spell identify} spell and can cast it without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Additionally, you ignore all class, race, and spell requirements on attuning to or using a magic item, provided that the magic item is a {@filter weapon|items|type=melee weapon;range=sor} or a {@item wand|phb}.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Weapon Mod
entries: At 10th level, you learn an additional weapon mod of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Lingering Magic
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you make an attack and expend a charge on one of your modded weapons, some of its magic lingers. The next time you make an attack with a different modded weapon on the same turn and expend one of its charges, you have advantage on the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Additional Weapon Mod
entries: At 15th level, you learn an additional weapon mod of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Backup Ammo
entries: At 18th level, while you are holding one of your modded weapons, you can use your bonus action to reload it. It regains one of its expended charges. You can use this feature three times. You regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Streets
entries: Monks of the Way of the Streets learn their techniques not through traditional monastic training, rather, they learn to defend themselves on the streets, taught by those they fight and others who must similarly fight to survive. They use these techniques not only in street brawls, but also in underground fighting tournaments, where monks of this way have made a name for themselves as powerful warriors capable of unleashing devastating combos.

subclassFeature.name: Street Smarts
entries: At 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Streetwise|ccg}, or {@skill Performance} skill (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Combos
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you unleash powerful combos against your opponents. Once per turn, when you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 1 ki point to launch into a combo against that creature.

When you begin your combo, you deal {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage to the target. If you roll a 3 or lower on this damage die, you repeat this bludgeoning damage with a {@damage d6} instead. If you roll a 3 or lower again, the effect repeats, increasing to a {@damage d8}, then a {@damage d10}, and finally a {@damage d12}. You gain no benefit if you roll a 3 or lower on the final d12. Your combo recieves no additional benefit from a triggering attack that resulted in a critical hit.

When your combo ends, you can force the target to make a Strength saving throw. On a failure, it is pushed back 5 feet away from you for each damage dice you rolled as a part of the combo. If the target is against a wall or other solid structure when they fail this saving throw, they take bludgeoning damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die instead of moving.
Starting at 11th level, the damage threshold for continuing your combo increases to 4.

subclassFeature.name: Signature Art
entries: At 6th level, you learn a special fighting technique that only you can utilize. Choose one of the following options for your signature art.
{@b Dragon Punch.} You finish your combos with a powerful uppercut. When a creature fails the Strength saving throw made at the end of one of your combos, they are also knocked {@condition prone}.
{@b Surging Fist.} You can unleash surges of energy from your fists. You can spend 2 ki points to cast the {@spell Guiding Bolt} spell as a bonus action, using Wisdom as your spellcasting ability.

{@b Wave Dash.} You move with incredible speed. Whenever you use your Step of the Wind, you gain the benefit of both the {@action Dash} and {@action Disengage} actions instead of only one of them, and you have advantage on the next attack roll you make on that turn.

subclassFeature.name: Ki-Fueled Combos
entries: Once you reach 6th level, the damage dealt by your combos counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. Also, you can spend 3 ki points instead of 1 when you enter a combo. If you do, you roll two dice at each stage of your combo, dealing the total as the damage for that stage. If either dice is below the damage threshold, the combo continues.

subclassFeature.name: Combo Breaker
entries: Starting at 11th level, when you are hit with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to deflect it by spending 1 ki point. When you do, the damage you take from the attack is reduced by 1d10 + your Dexterity modifier + your monk level. If you reduce the damage to 0, you can make a single unarmed strike against the creature that attacked you as a part of the same reaction, provided they are within range.

subclassFeature.name: Ultra Technique
entries: At 17th level, you can unleash your ultimate technique at the end of a perfect combo. After you roll a d12 as a part of one of your combos, you can spend 1 ki point to unleash a powerful finishing move against the target. If you do and the target fails the Strength saving throw made at the end of the combo, the target is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A paralyzed target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again within the next minute.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Rebellion
entries: The Oath of Rebellion is a powerful commitment to strike back against oppressors. At times where corrupt leaders and powerful organizations abuse their powers and restrict the freedoms of their patrons, these paladins arise to fight for and inspire those who cannot fight for themselves. They seek great change, even at the cost of using underhanded tactics, and understand they cannot make change alone, aiming to instead be the icon for others to follow.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Rebellion
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Rebellion drive a paladin to fight for those oppressed by authority.

entries.name: Fight Against Oppression
entries: Never turn your back on those suffering injustice or cruelty. Fight for their freedom and the freedom of all.

entries.name: Fight for Equality
entries: Demand and fight for the fair treatment of all. Never turn your back to those treated with disrespect or unfair judgment.

entries.name: Lead the Rebellion
entries: Be the spark that ignites the rebellion. Lead the charge with your companions to make great changes in this world and stand with them no matter the cost.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Break the Shackles
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to cleanse debilitating affects. As an action, you present your holy symbol and choose one creature within 30 feet of you. It regains hit points equal to 1d6 + your paladin level, and one condition of your choice afflicting it ends. The condition can be {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition poisoned}, {@condition restrained}, or {@condition stunned}. You can use this action even while you are incapacitated, so long as you have at least 1 hit point.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Stand Your Ground
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to empower your resolve. As a bonus action, you grant yourself a +5 bonus to Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks for the next 10 minutes.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Equality
entries: Starting at 7th level, you emanate an equalizing aura while you are not {@condition incapacitated}, which extends 10 feet from you in every direction.

When a beneficial spell of 5th level or lower that targets a single creature and that has a duration longer than instantaneous, such as {@spell shield of faith} or {@spell invisibility}, is cast within 60 feet of you, you can use your reaction to capture some of spell's magic. You then begin to release it through your aura. All creatures inside the aura share the benefits of the spell for its duration or until you lose concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell). If a creature leaves the aura, they lose the benefits until they return. You do not need to use your reaction to capture a spell's magic this way if you were the one to cast it.

You can only have one spell active through this aura at a time. If you capture the magic of another spell, your aura immediately stops emitting the benefits of the previous spell. If you capture the magic of a spell that marks a particular creature, such as {@spell hunter's mark}, all creatures inside the aura also gain the benefits provided by the spell against the original caster, as if they were the target of the spell, in addition to the original target. Lastly, you cannot capture the magic of 'aura' spells with this feature.
Once you reach 18th level, you can extend the range of this aura. You can switch between a smaller (10 feet) or a larger (30 feet) aura as a bonus action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Icon of Persistence
entries: At 15th level, you can grant your allies courage and strike with them. When a creature within 10 feet of you misses an attack roll, you can use your reaction to grant them a bonus to the roll equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1), potentially changing the outcome. If this causes the attack to hit, you can make one weapon attack against the creature your ally attacked as a part of the same reaction, provided they are within range.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Insurgence
entries: At 20th level, you can harness the force of all those who rebel with you. As an action, you gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You have resistance to all damage.
While you have at least 1 hit point, you are immune to all non-beneficial conditions.
You and all friendly creatures within 30 feet have their speed increased by 10 feet and gain a bonus to attack rolls equal to the number of allies within that area (a maximum bonus of +5).

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Infernal Rider
entries: Infernal Rider Rangers roam both the streets inside Prismatic Falls and the wastes outside of it, using high-powered arcane cycles to get around in both speed and style. They often roam in small groups, using specially made vehicles that allow them to fight while riding. The screams of fiends are a sign that an ambush from one of these gangs is imminent.

subclassFeature.name: Ready to Ride
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn the {@spell mending} cantrip and gain proficiency in all vehicles. Also, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the table below. A spell learned this way counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Cycle
entries: At 3rd level, you gain access to a special arcane cycle, which is a motorbike-like mechanical vehicle that you can utilize in and out of combat. It is powered by your choice of two tiny fiends, such as {@creature imp||Imps} or {@creature quasit||Quasits}. The vehicle can magically compress into a small rod, which you can carry on your person. As a bonus action on your turn, you can touch the rod to have it expand into the cycle under you, provided there is enough space to do so. You can also use your bonus action to turn the cycle back into the rod if you are riding it.

The cycle is a Large* magical vehicle with an AC equal to your Wisdom Score and a number of hit points equal to four times your ranger level. It is immune to poison and psychic damage, as well as all conditions. If it is forced to make an ability check or saving throw, treat all of its ability scores as equal to your Wisdom score. It compresses back into a small rod when it is reduced to 0 hit points and can't turn back into its cycle form until it regains at least 1 hit point. When the {@spell mending} spell is cast on it in either form, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points.

Only you can ride the cycle. While riding it, your movement each turn is 60 feet, but when you move, you cannot rotate more than 90 degrees each turn. At the start of each of your turns, you can choose a different direction for the bike, turning it on the spot before you begin moving. Any increase to your speed applies to the cycle while you ride it, including if you take the {@action Dash} action. Creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attacks against you and your cycle while you ride it. While you ride your cycle, you can force any attack targeted at you to target it, or vice versa.

If you move the cycle for at least three turns in a single direction, it can move at its max speed of 700 feet and acts as a regular vehicle, using the {@vehicle Arcane Cycle|ccg} stat block. Even though your cycle acts as a regular vehicle in this case, you cannot fit it with vehicle upgrades.
{@note *When playing on a 5 ft. grid, the cycle takes up a 2 × 1 area.}

subclassFeature.name: Momentum Strike
entries: At 3rd level, if you move at least 20 feet in a straight line then hit a melee weapon attack, it deals an extra {@damage 1d4} damage to the target.
The extra damage increases to {@damage 1d6} when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Fiendish Power
entries: Starting at 7th level, while you are riding your cycle, you can use your bonus action to draw an infernal power from the fiends inside, choosing one of the benefits below:

{@b Flame Trail.} The next time your cycle moves on that turn, it leaves behind a 1-foot wide, 5-foot high trail of fire until it stops moving. The trail disappears after 1 minute. Creatures can see, move, and make ranged attacks through the trail, but whenever a creature passes through it or ends its turn within the trail, it must make a Dexterity saving throw. It takes fire damage equal to 2d8 + your Wisdom modifier on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.
{@b Infernal Flight.} Your cycle has a flying speed of 30 feet for the next minute, and it has the ability to hover for the duration.
You can use either of these features a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ramming Strike
entries: At 11th level, you augment your cycle to allow you to ram your enemies. When you deal the extra damage of your {@subclassFeature Momentum Strike|Ranger||Infernal Rider|ccg|3} while riding your combat cycle, you can have the target make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC if they are no larger than Huge. On a failed save, they are carried along with your cycle until it stops moving. If you hit a solid surface, both the cycle and the target stop moving early, and the target is knocked {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Evasive Maneuvers
entries: Starting at 15 level, you can nimbly maneuver your cycle in combat. When you move on your cycle, there is no limit to how much you can rotate each turn.

Additionally, when the cycle is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails. You also gain this benefit while you are riding the cycle.

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: Rogues of this archetype are master gunslingers and smooth-talking outlaws who always shoot first. They react with incredible speed, relying on their instincts and skills to shoot down any threat before it can even make a move.

subclassFeature.name: Smooth Talker
entries: At 3rd level, you are an adept at getting what you want through conversation. If you fail a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) or Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check, you can roll an additional d20 and use the result, potentially changing the outcome. You must use the new roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Opening Shot
entries: Starting at 3rd level, directly after you roll Initiative while not {@quickref Surprise||3||surprised}, you can use your reaction to make a single weapon attack with advantage against a creature you can see. When you do, you also choose from one of the following additional effects for your opening shot:

{@b Deadeye.} If the attack hits, it deals extra damage equal to a roll of half the number of Sneak Attack dice for your level (rounded down). Also, if it is a ranged attack, its range and the range of any other ranged attack you make as a part of the reaction are doubled.

{@b Roll.} Before or after making the attack roll, you move up to your speed without provoking opportunity attacks. Additionally, you gain temporary hit points equal to a roll of half the number of Sneak Attack dice for your level (rounded down), which last for the next minute.

{@b Trip.} If the attack hits, the target must make a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your Dexterity modifier + your proficiency bonus), or you knock them prone and can cause them to drop one object of your choice that they are holding.

If you use your reaction to make an opening shot, you can't use your action on your first turn in combat. You can draw up to two one-handed weapons as a part of the reaction, and if you can engage in two weapon fighting, you can make the additional attack as a part of the reaction, but none of the above effects apply to the second attack, except for Deadeye's range increase.

subclassFeature.name: Showdown
entries: At 9th level, you can invoke a sacred duel. As an action, you make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check contested by a creature's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The creature must be within 30 feet of you, must be able to hear you, and it must share at least one language with you.

If you succeed on the check, both you and the creature are bound by the duel for the next minute. While in the duel, both you and the target cannot attack or cast harmful spells on any other creature. During the duel, you can use your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|rogue||1} against the target even if you don't have advantage on the attack roll, but not if you have disadvantage on it. Also, creatures not in the duel have disadvantage on attack rolls against both you and the target.

The duel ends early if either you or the target is {@condition incapacitated} or when you and the target are more than 120 feet apart. It also ends if a creature friendly to you damages the target or casts a harmful spell on it, or if you end it as a bonus action on your turn.
You can take this action even on your first turn after using your {@subclassFeature opening shot|Rogue||Quickdraw|ccg|3}, when you could not normally take an action.

subclassFeature.name: Cunning Outlaw
entries: Starting at 13th level, you can't be surprised while you are conscious. Additionally, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks to determine whether someone is lying to you.

subclassFeature.name: Vigilant Shot
entries: Starting at 17th level, you are even quicker on the draw. When you use your {@subclassFeature opening shot|Rogue||Quickdraw|ccg|3}, you can choose two effects instead of one.

subclassFeature.name: Nightmare Origin
entries: In a nightmare, a dark force buried itself within you, manifesting the fears of those around you within your body and awakening your sorcerous powers. Your mind and flesh took the form of these collective nightmares, allowing you to manipulate their power into spells. Now, as the nightmare personified, you are able to call upon the powers of the void.

subclassFeature.name: Incarnation of Fear
entries: At 1st level, you morph into an incarnation of fear. Whenever you finish a short or long rest, roll on the table below to determine your incarnation, which lasts until you finish your next short or long rest.

Each incarnation lists two spells, one available to you at 1st level and another available to you once you reach 3rd level. While an incarnation is active, you know the listed spells, and each counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but they don't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.
Additionally, you gain an effect based on your current Incarnation while it is active, as detailed below.
{@b Arachnid.} You can move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings while leaving your hands free.
{@b Disease.} When a creature hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to deal necrotic damage to them equal to your proficiency bonus.
{@b Gloom.} You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 60 feet.
{@b Serpent.} Your walking speed increases by 10 feet. Also, you gain a swimming speed of 30 feet.
{@b Judgment.} You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks against creatures that can see or hear you.
{@b Thunder.} Once per turn when you deal damage to a creature, you can move them up to 5 feet in any direction of your choice, except upwards.
When you reach 3rd level, you can spend 1 sorcery point as a bonus action to switch your current incarnation to another one of your choice.

entries.name: Variant Incarnations
entries: If you want your nightmare sorcerer to feel a bit more specialized, you can use this variant. Instead of rolling random incarnations, choose one of the available options when you choose this origin, which becomes active for you. After you finish a long rest, you can choose a different incarnation to switch to. Your incarnation can't change otherwise.
Once you gain the Anomalous Form feature, you can choose another incarnation to become active for you, which you can also switch it after a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Void Rift
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can tear a rift in reality, summoning an aberrant creature from the void to fight alongside you. As a bonus action, you can spend 3 sorcery points to summon a {@creature Void Lurker|ccg} in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of you.

The lurker is friendly to you and your companions and obeys your commands. Its statistics are detailed below, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places. You determine the lurker's appearance, which is often a vile monster reminiscent of common phobias and fears.

In combat, the lurker shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. The only action it takes on its turn is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take another action. That action can be one in its stat block or some other action. On the turn you summon the lurker, you can command it as a part of the bonus action used to summon it. If you are incapacitated, the lurker can take any action of its choice, not just Dodge.
The lurker disappears and returns to its home plane after 1 hour or after it is reduced to 0 hit points. It also returns if you use this feature to summon a lurker again, or if you die.

subclassFeature.name: Anomalous Form
entries: At 14th level, your form is corrupted further by the void. When you roll for or choose your incarnation, you gain two instead of one (re-rolling duplicates). They both remain active until you finish your next short or long rest.
Additionally, you can breathe in air and water, as well as communicate telepathically to any creature you can see within 30 feet of you, so long as they share a language with you.

subclassFeature.name: Dreadful Collapse
entries: At 18th level, you can cause a burst of shadowy energy to erupt from you as a bonus action on your turn. Creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, a target is teleported to another space of your choice within 30 feet of you and is {@condition frightened} of you for the next minute. A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest, unless you spend 5 sorcery points to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: The Lost Soul
entries: You have made a pact with a soul lost in the Ethereal Plane, a wanderer of the place between life and death. Trapped within an endless ethereal expanse, the lost soul may have motivations to correct whatever mistakes they made in life, and otherwise watches over you with curiosity. Using its powers, you become a master of its domain. Many warlocks of this pact are part of the mysterious Wanderer Cult

entries.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Lost Soul lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Eerie Resolve
entries: Starting at 1st level, you have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Knowledge
entries: At 1st level, lost souls grant you mystical knowledge through whispers. Whenever you finish a long rest, you can gain proficiency in any two skills of your choice. If you are already proficient in either of the skills you choose, your proficiency bonus is instead doubled for any check you make with that skill.
You lose all of the benefits of this feature when you use it to gain skill proficiencies again.

subclassFeature.name: Ethereal Scout
entries: At 6th level, you learn the {@spell ethereal jaunt|ccg} spell if you don't know it already. It counts as a warlock spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of warlock spells you know. You can cast the spell once without expending a spell slot, and you regain the ability to do so after you finish a long rest.
Additionally, you gain the following benefits while under the effects of the spell:

items: For the duration of the spell, you can use your bonus action to return to your mortal body or project back into your ethereal body if you've already returned.

While in your ethereal body, you can place a spectral mark on the soul of a creature you can see. Creatures with such a mark on their soul have disadvantage on Initiative rolls. You can have a maximum number of marks active at any time equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1). If you place more, the earliest one you placed disappears.
While in your ethereal body, your material body isn't {@condition paralyzed}, and you are semi-conscious of its surroundings.
When you try to {@variantrule 'Hacking' the Material|ccg|pierce the veil} in Soulspace, you automatically succeed on the ability check required to do so.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Haunting
entries: Once you reach 10th level, you can affect creatures across planes. While you are in the ethereal body granted by the {@spell ethereal jaunt|ccg} spell, you can target the souls of creatures you can see with your warlock spells, as if you were targeting that creature in the Material Plane. Spells you cast this way can't deal damage.

Also, you can cast one spell of 3rd-level or lower while in your ethereal body without expending a spell slot, provided you target a single soul you can see. Once you do, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Possession
entries: Starting at 14th level, you gain the ability to posses humanoids. You can cast the {@spell dominate person} spell once without expending a spell slot. When you cast it, you must be in the ethereal body granted by the {@spell ethereal jaunt|ccg} spell, and you must remain in that body for the duration of the spell. When you cast the dominate person spell this way, it lasts up to 1 hour.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Infiltration Magic
entries: You use your magic as a tool for tactical operations, experimenting and exploring the possibilities of how you can infiltrate the most well-guarded locations. Followers of this tradition learn how to manipulate and disable arcane devices in their path and are cunning with their spell usage.

subclassFeature.name: Infiltrator
entries: At 2nd level, you learn to compliment your spells with more practical infiltration tactics. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill and in {@item thieves' tools|ccg} if you don't already have those proficiencies.

subclassFeature.name: Disrupt Magic
entries: At 2nd level, you learn to pull at raw arcane energy, disrupting it for short periods of time. As an action, you can choose one object within 15 feet of you. If it is a magical item or a magically imbued object, its magical properties cease to function for 10 minutes. If any spells are affecting the item, such as the {@spell arcane lock} spell, they also cease to function if they are of 5th-level or lower for 10 minutes. If the object is particularly powerful, complex, or large, your GM might determine that its magic is instead dampened, or that only a portion of its magical properties are affected. Some highly potent arcane objects might resist this feature entirely. If your GM determines that is the case, you instead learn the object's magical properties, as if you cast the {@spell identify} spell on it.

Instead of choosing an object, you can choose one creature you can see within 15 feet of you. Until the end of your next turn, any spells of 5th-level or lower affecting them have their effects nullified, they can't cast spells, and they can't use devices that require the use of their magic, such as magic items or arcane firearms. Also, if they are concentrating on a spell, they immediately lose concentration on it.

If you target an object held or worn by a hostile creature or if you target an unwilling creature with this feature, that creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your wizard spell save DC to avoid the feature's effects.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Devious Arsenal
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you develop an arsenal of spells suited specifically for infiltration. The following spells are added to your spellbook if they haven't been added to it already. Each counts as a wizard spell for you.

entries.caption: Infitration Spells
rows: {@spell find traps}, {@spell knock}, {@spell mute|ccg}, {@spell pass without trace}
{@spell arcane eye}, {@spell dimension door}, {@spell Leomund's secret chest||secret chest}

entries: Whenever you prepare your list of spells at the end of a long rest, you can prepare an additional number of spells equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of 1 extra spell). Each of these additional prepared spells must be from the above table.

Additionally, whenever you cast one of the spells listed in the above table using a spell slot, you regain one expended spell slot. The slot you regain must be of a level lower than the spell you cast.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Translocation
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can place a magical sigil on the ground below you whenever you cast a spell of 3rd-level or higher, which is invisible to all creatures except you. While you are within 120 feet of a sigil, you can teleport to it as a bonus action on your turn. The sigil then disappears. It also disappears if you place a new one with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Camouflage
entries: Starting at 14th level, you learn to draw at the latent magic of your spells to camouflage yourself. After you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, you can choose to become {@condition invisible} until the end of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Method of Innovation
entries: You personally manufacture the form you desire, which consists of constructed enhancements and fabricated body parts. While most evolutionists of this method enhance themselves with intricate, magical technology, some prefer to instead use earthen, elemental augmentations or stitched pieces of monsters. Regardless, evolutionists of this method are resilient and innovative. They constantly tinker, repair, and fine tune themselves, continually building towards something greater.

subclassFeature.name: Tinkerer
entries: When you choose this method at 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@item tinker's tools|ccg} and {@item thieves' tools|ccg} if you don't already have them.

subclassFeature.name: Self Repair
entries: Starting at 1st level, your form allows for quick reconstruction. As a bonus action, you can repair your broken parts, regaining hit points equal to 1d6 + your evolutionist level. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ingenious Enhancements
entries: At 7th level, you innovate new enhancements. Choose two additional {@filter upgrades|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=EU} to develop. These upgrades don't need to meet any augmentation prerequisites, don't count against the maximum number of upgrades you can develop, and they are always activated for you. If you choose upgrades that provide you a choice when activated, you can make that choice when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Stabilized Ignition
entries: Starting at 13th level, you modify your enhancements to cause less strain on your body. The base hit point reduction for your {@classFeature Metabolic Ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3} is now equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Omega Cannon
entries: Starting at 17th level while you are ignited, you can use your action to unleash a final destructive blast, forming a line 100 feet long and 15 feet wide in front of you. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 12d6} lighting, radiant, or fire damage (your choice) on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The blast ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried, and does quadruple damage to all objects and structures.

After you use this feature, you are pushed 30 feet backwards from the direction you fired, your metabolic ignition and all of its benefits immediately end, and you can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Method of Mutation
entries: Your body is greatly mutated: flesh morphed, resized, and reconfigured. Parts grown, and possibly changed in color. These mutations could be included through a vile practice of alchemy, a powerful curse, or a symbiotic relationship with a parasitic creature. No matter the method, these evolutionists live on the edge—constantly pushing their body to its limit. When they modify themselves, their bodies undergo chaotic, potent transformations that push the boundaries of their psyche.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemist
entries: When you choose this method at 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@item alchemist's supplies|ccg} and the {@item poisoner's kit|ccg} if you don't already have them.

subclassFeature.name: Mutant Reflexes
entries: Starting at 1st level, your mutated form heightens your reflexes. You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your Constitution modifier.

Additionally, when you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn and miss an attack, you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action that turn. You can do so a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Berserk Mutation
entries: Starting at 7th level when you ignite a single augmentation, you can choose to enter a berserk state for the duration of your ignition. If you do, you instead ignite a random one of your augmentations and switch to a new random augmentation at the start of each of your turns while you remain ignited, determined by rolling {@dice 1d3}.

Your size increases by one category for the duration—from Medium to Large, for example, causing your weapon attacks to deal {@damage 1d4} extra damage on a hit. Also, when a creature deals damage to you or ends their turn within your range while you are in this berserk state, you can make one weapon attack against them as a reaction.
Once you enter this berserk state, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Chaotic Mutation
entries: At 13th level, you can invoke a chaotic mutation within yourself. As a bonus action, you can gain a random augmentation out of those you lack, determined by rolling {@dice 1d3}. Then, you gain a random Upgrade from that augmentation's category, determined by rolling {@dice 1d6}.

You gain the benefits of the augmentation and upgrade for the next hour, or until you use this feature again. If either offers you a choice, you make that choice when you gain the augmentation or upgrade through this feature.

You can ignite this new augmentation, and you can enter your Metabolic Ignition as a part of the same bonus action used to gain it, provided you ignite the new augmentation as a part of it or use your {@subclassFeature Berserk Mutation|Evolutionist|ccg|Mutation|ccg|7} feature when you ignite. If you use your Berserk Mutation feature with this extra augmentation, roll {@dice 1d4} each turn to determine the random augmentation that is ignited.
You can use this feature three times. You regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Wrathful Surge
entries: Starting at 17th level you can push your body to extreme limits. If you start your turn ignited and choose to remain ignited, you can take an additional turn in combat directly after this one. During this turn, you must move directly towards the closest creature until you are within range to attack. Then, you must use the {@action Attack} action against them, using all your possible attacks, moving to attack the next creature if you fell your current target.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Method of Infusion
entries: Your form is intensely magical—infused within you is the power of pure arcana. You weave this power to shape magical, iridescent enhancements— translucent limbs, lustrous, glowing eyes, or even tattoo-like augmentations that wrap around your body. You could have received this power at birth, or it might have been imbued within you at some point in your life. Perhaps a higher being granted you such power. No matter its origin, its your process that allows for your enhancements—as you weave your body in the same way that a mage weaves their spells.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: At 1st level, your arcane form grants you the ability to cast spells.

{@b Cantrips.} You learn {@filter one cantrip of your choice from the sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=sorcerer}. You learn an additional cantrip of your choice at 3rd level and another at 10th level.

{@b Spell Slots.} The Infusion Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level or higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
{@b Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher.} When you choose this method, you know two {@filter 1st-level sorcerer spells|spells|level=1|class=sorcerer} of your choice.

The Spells Known column of the Infusion Spellcasting table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of 1st-level or higher. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

{@b Spellcasting Ability.} Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since your arcane power comes from within you. You use Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
{@b Augmented Focus.} You can use any modified part of your body as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Sense
entries: Starting at 1st level, you are innately connected to the magic around you. You learn the {@spell identify} and {@spell detect magic spells} and they don't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. You can cast either of them without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Form
entries: Starting at 7th level when you first ignite, you can choose to transform your body into pure magic for the duration of your {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignition}. While in this form, you gain the following benefits:

items: After you cast a spell, you can teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of one of the spell's targets or a point within its area of effect, so long as you can see the target location.
All spells you cast during the ignition are cast at one level higher than the spell slot used to cast them.

entries: Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Body
entries: At 13th level, you take no damage and are unaffected by any other detrimental effects from spells you cast. If you would take damage from a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher that you cast, you instead regain {@dice 2d6} hit points. A spell can only cause you to regain hit points this way once.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Strike
entries: At 17th level when you take the {@action Attack} action, you can replace one of the attacks with a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, which you cast as a part of the same action.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline of Soothsaying
entries: Those who follow the Discipline of Soothsaying focus on enhancing their connection to the ethereal, granting them clairvoyant abilities. These soulshapers serve as oracles that channel and decipher omens delivered by spirits in order to predict the future.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline Spells
entries: You learn a discipline spell at each of the levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Spiritual Visions
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your otherworldly connection allows spirits to deliver mysterious omens to you. You can spend 10 minutes performing a seance to receive three visions, which last until you finish your next short or long rest. Once you perform a seance, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

When you or a allied creature within 60 feet that can hear you makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can use your reaction to expend a vision and grant them advantage on the roll. You do so by warning them of an incoming threat, informing them of a weak point, or telling them any other useful information that could be provided by your vision, as the true meaning of the omen is revealed to you. You can also expend a vision as a reaction when a hostile creature makes an attack against you or one of your allies within 60 feet that can hear you, imposing disadvantage on the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Soothsayer's Rituals
entries: At 2nd level, you learn to cast rituals through the aid of spirits. You can cast any soulshaper spell you know as a ritual if the spell has a ritual tag.

Also, you have a set of additional spells which you can cast only as rituals. When you gain this feature, your set of ritual spells contains the {@spell augury} spell and any {@filter two 1st-level ritual spells of your choice from the bard, cleric, or druid spell lists|spells|level=1|class=druid;bard;cleric|components & miscellaneous=ritual}. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the spells in the set and replace it with another ritual spell from any of those spell lists. The spell's level must be no higher than half your soulshaper level (rounded up).

subclassFeature.name: Spirit's Blessing
entries: Beginning at 5th level, when you use your action to cast a soulshaper spell, you can call a spirit to aid a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Once before the end of their next turn, the creature can roll {@dice 1d8} and add the number rolled to one attack roll or damage roll they make. Alternatively, if the spell you cast was a {@filter soulshaper spell that restores hit points|spells|class=soulshaper (ccg)|components & miscellaneous=hl}, you can call the spirit to add {@dice 1d8} to the number of hit points restored for one creature.

subclassFeature.name: Guidance of the Spirits
entries: Starting at 10th level, whenever you expend a vision to grant an ally advantage on a roll, you can also end either the {@condition frightened} condition or {@condition charmed} condition on the target. Also, they regain hit points equal to 1d6 + your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Summon Spirit
entries: At 15th level, you can use your bonus action to summon a spirit from the Ethereal Plane, which appears in a space within 30 feet of you. The spirit is intangible and disappears after 1 minute. As a part of the bonus action used to summon it and as a bonus action on each of your turns thereafter, you can cause the spirit to affect one creature within 10 feet of it, choosing one of the following options:
{@b Spectral Shield.} The target gains temporary hit points equal to 1d8 + your Wisdom modifier, which last until the spirit disappears.

{@b Decaying Touch.} Make a melee spell attack against the target. On a hit, it takes necrotic damage equal to 1d8 + your Wisdom modifier. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline of Witchcraft
entries: Those who follow the Discipline of Witchcraft train and experiment with their abilities to manipulate the souls of others. Some do this to enhance their combat capabilities, while others do it to see how far they can push their powers. In either case, live subjects are required for their experiments, which tend to push these soulshapers into lives of reclusivity, where they experiment with rats and other vermin to explore their spiritual powers.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline Spells
entries: You learn a discipline spell at each of the levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Bound Familiar
entries: At 2nd level, you learn to place magical bindings on the souls of animals an in order to control them. As an action, you can choose a {@filter Tiny, non-hostile beast|bestiary|type=beast|size=t} within 30 feet of you and bind it to your service. (This is likely to be a {@creature rat}, {@creature raven}, {@creature cat}, or {@creature spider} in Prismatic Falls). It becomes your familiar, abiding by all of the effects of the {@spell find familiar} spell, except the familiar is a beast and you cannot choose to dismiss it forever. You can only have one animal bound this way at a time. If you use this feature again, the previous beast is no longer bound to your service.
Additionally, while you have such a familiar, you can cast the {@spell animal messenger} spell on it as a ritual. This frees it from service as your familiar.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Brand
entries: Also starting at 2nd level, you learn to curse creatures by placing brands on their soul. As a bonus action, you can place a spectral brand on a creature within 60 feet of you, which lasts for 1 minute. Whenever that creature makes an attack roll or saving throw, it must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the result. If a creature with this brand drops to 0 hit points before the effect ends, you can use a bonus action on a subsequent turn of yours to brand a new creature within range. Alternatively, you can use this bonus action to siphon energy from the target's soul. This ends your brand and causes you to regain hit points equal to 1d4 + your Wisdom modifier.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ruinous Witchery
entries: Beginning at 5th level, whenever you cast a soulshaper cantrip, you can add your Wisdom modifier to one of its damage rolls. Additionally, whenever you use your action to cast a soulshaper spell of 1st level or higher, you can cause one of the targets to take force, radiant, or necrotic damage (your choice) equal to your Wisdom modifier. You can deal this damage even if the target wasn't affected by the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Shackle
entries: At 10th level, whenever you place a spectral brand, you can place it on two creatures instead of one, which must be within 15 feet of each other. Those creatures are then mystically linked for the duration, which affects them in the following ways:

items: The creatures can't move further than 15 feet away from each other.

Whenever one of the creatures is affected by a condition, except for the {@condition unconscious} condition, you can force the other creature to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failure, that creature is also affected by the condition while it persists on the original target.
Whenever one of the creatures takes damage, you can use your reaction to deal {@damage 1d6} damage of the same type to the other creature.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Control
entries: At 15th level, when a creature you can see makes an attack, you can use your reaction to tug on their soul, forcing them to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failure, you redirect the attack to any other target of your choice within range that you can see.
You can use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline of Manifestation
entries: Those who follow the Discipline of Manifestation are brawlers who focus on the ability to summon a physical incarnation of their soul. The incarnation they manifest is often an augmented representation of themselves; stronger, faster, with a magnificent appearance shaped by their core emotions.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline Spells
entries: You learn a discipline spell at each of the levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Manifest Soul
entries: When you choose this discipline at 2nd level, you gain the ability to manifest your soul as an ethereal guardian to fight for you. You can summon and dismiss this manifestation at will (no action required). Your manifestation occupies your space, is intangible, and grants you the following benefits while it is active:

{@b Soul Strike.} As an action, you can command your manifestation to strike, making a melee spell attack against a creature within 10 feet of you. On a hit, it deals damage equal to 2d6 + your Wisdom modifier. The damage type is force, radiant, or necrotic (your choice when you summon your manifestation). Your reach is considered to be 10 feet in regard to opportunity attacks. Whenever you make an opportunity attack, you can command your manifestation to make this attack against the target instead, in place of that attack.
The damage dice of this attack increases to 2d8 once you reach 10th level and it increases again to 2d10 once you reach 15th level.

{@b Deflect.} When a creature within 10 feet of you hits a melee attack against you or another creature within that range, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage the target takes by 1d8 + your proficiency bonus (to a minimum of 0 damage).
{@b Brawn.} While your manifestation is active, you can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Strength modifier when making Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Scout
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to send your soul manifestation out short distances to scout areas. As an action, you can turn your manifestation {@condition invisible} and gain the ability to see through its eyes for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you are blind in regard to your own senses. You can use your action to control your manifestation, allowing it to manipulate objects. You can move your manifestation up to 30 feet each time you use it, and it can be a maximum of 60 feet away from you at any given time. Your manifestation can carry a maximum of 20 pounds.

You lose all of the benefits of your Manifest Soul feature while the manifestation is in this state. You can dismiss this state at any time (no action required), at which time your manifestation immediately returns to your space. Your manifestation drops anything it is holding before it returns.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Brawl
entries: At 5th level, when you use your action to command your manifestation to use its soul strike, you can command it to make two soul strikes instead of one. Also, you can now command your manifestation to grapple or shove a target in place of one or both of its soul strikes, provided the target is within 10 feet. When you do, you make the required ability check in place of your manifestation.

subclassFeature.name: Beatdown
entries: At 10th level, you can command your manifestation to unleash a rapid flurry of strikes as an action. It makes three soul strikes, which you can individually direct against creatures of your choice within range. A target hit by one of these soul strikes must make a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of its next turn.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Flash Strike
entries: At 15th level, your manifestation can move at an incredible speed. When a creature you can see makes an attack, you can use your reaction to immediately take an extra turn before the attack is resolved. During this extra turn, you can't use your movement, but you can use your Beatdown feature without expending its use.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline of Soulblades
entries: Those who follow the Discipline of Soulblades specialize in manifesting their soul into spectral weaponry. The form of the weapons they conjure is often intricate and personal, driven by their core emotions. These soulshapers are often wanderers or thieves, who use their conjured soulblades to defend themselves when necessary.

subclassFeature.name: Discipline Spells
entries: You learn a discipline spell at each of the levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Conjure Soulblades
entries: At 2nd level, you learn how to conjure soulblades, weapons made out of spiritual energy that you draw from your soul. As an action, you can conjure up to two of these weapons. You choose the form of each weapon, which can be melee or ranged, from the weapon options you are using in your game. You are proficient with weapons you conjure this way, and you can use your Wisdom modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for their attack and damage rolls.
