Whenever you conjure a soulblade, you choose whether it deals force, radiant or necrotic damage, which it deals instead of its regular damage type.

You can have a maximum of two soulblades active at a time. If you conjure a third one, the earliest one you created disappears. A soulblade you created also disappears if it is more than 5 feet away from you for 1 minute or more, if you dismiss the weapon (no action required), or if you die. At the end of your turn, you can choose to return any of your soulblades that are not in your possession back to into your hands.
When you make an attack with a soulblade, you can choose to do so with advantage. If you do, the soulblade is destroyed after the attack, regardless of if you hit or missed.

subclassFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Also at 2nd level, you adopt a style of fighting as your specialty. Choose a {@filter Fighting Style from those available to the Fighter class|optionalfeatures|feature type=fs:f}. You can't take the same Fighting Style option more than once, even if something in the game lets you choose again.

subclassFeature.name: Wanderer's Poise
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion} skill (your choice). Also, choose one of those skills. Whenever you make a check with it, you can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn and only attack with soulblades.
Once you reach 15th level, the number of attacks you can make increases to three.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Trance
entries: At 10th level, you enter a spiritual trance whenever you are maintaining concentration on a spell, granting you the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on all Constitution saving throws made to maintain your concentration on the spell.
You can't be {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.
Creatures you can see have disadvantage on opportunity attacks against you.
At the start of each of your turns, you can conjure one soulblade (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack (2)
entries: At 15th level, you can attack three times whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn and only attack with soulblades.

subclassFeature.name: Soulblade Overdrive
entries: At 15th level, you can enlarge your soulblades to an enormous size. When you start to take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, you can choose to enter a spiritual overdrive for the next minute.

While in this overdrive, any soulblades you are wielding are enlarged to an enormous size, as are any you conjure for the duration. The damage dice of these enlarged soulblades are doubled, and only you can wield them while they are enlarged this way. Once your overdrive ends, any active soulblades of yours revert back to their original size.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

language.name: Common
typicalSpeakers: Prismatic Falls; trade language across all of Aysta

language.name: Imperial
entries: {@b Imperial} is the harsh, practical language of the Shattered Empire derived from both {@language Elvish|ccg} and {@language Orcish|ccg}.

language.name: Runic
entries: {@b Runic} is a language that is only written, making up the contents of all runic magic across Aysta.

language.name: Wild
entries: {@b Wild} is the rhythmic, gentle language of the beastfolk, adapted from the Fey that lived among them.

language.name: Ancient
entries: {@b Ancient} is the language of the long-dead Precursors. Few today can understand it, and none can speak it.

language.name: Eternal
entries: {@b Eternal} is the intricate, menacing language of the eternals, seemingly derived from {@language Ancient|ccg}.

language.name: Nomadic
entries: {@b Nomadic} is the language of the otherworldly nomads, consisting of specifically ordered musical tones.

background.name: Mercenary

_.special: one other pack of your choice

entries: You are a mercenary for hire, a skilled freelancer capable of completing a variety of difficult missions. You've spent a lot of time on such missions and are used to dangerous scenarios. You may specialize in a particular area, such as body guarding, infiltration, or hit jobs, but you'll often take whatever you can get.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: Two of your choice among {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Athletics}, {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Perception}, {@skill Stealth}, and {@skill Streetwise|ccg}.

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: Any one type of vehicle ({@filter land|vehicles|terrain=land}, {@filter water|vehicles|terrain=sea}, or {@filter air|vehicles|terrain=air}) or {@item thieves' tools|ccg}.

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Gear Packs:
items.entry: {@item Pathfinding gear|ccg} or a set of {@item thieves' tools|ccg}, as well as {@filter one other pack of your choice|items|type=regular gear pack;tool gear pack}.

entries.name: Feature: Freelancer
entries: Through your experience on missions, you've met many others in your line of work. You have connections to other mercenaries and fixers who may aid you with obscure information or recommended you for high paying missions.

background.name: Shaman

_.special: one other pack of your choice

entries: You are a shaman, a protector of the less fortunate in the slums of Prismatic Falls or similar places that are in need of aid. You are a guide for the lost and use magic or herbal remedies to ensure the safety of those who have none other to look out for them.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: Two of your choice from {@skill Religion}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Nature}, and {@skill Navigation|ccg}.

items.name: Tools:
items.entry: {@item Alchemist's supplies|ccg} or {@item chemist's tools|ccg}.

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Cantrip (in place of a skill):
items.entry: {@spell spare the dying}

items.name: Spells (each in place of a tool or language):
items.entry: {@spell protection from evil and good}, {@spell augury}, {@spell lesser restoration}

items.name: Gear Packs:
items.entry: {@item Alchemist's supplies|ccg} or {@item chemist's tools|ccg}, as well as {@filter one other pack of your choice|items|type=regular gear pack;tool gear pack}.

entries.name: Feature: Returning the Favor
entries: You have provided aid to many in the slums of Prismatic Falls and beyond. Many of those who you have helped will often be willing to return the favor, in whatever small ways they can.

spell.name: Binding Contract

components.m: a drop of your own blood and a drop of blood from the target

entries: You place the palm of your hand on the palm of a creature that shares a language with you, envisioning the terms of a contract in your mind. It must contain two things: objectives for the target creature and/or yourself achievable within the next 5 days, and a punishment for each creature involved should they fail their objective (which need not be the same). There is no limit to the number of objectives for either creature, and the objectives can be anything you like, including a restriction on a creature's actions for the duration. For example, you could have the target perform a dangerous task, while you must give them a precious item of yours, and have both agree to not intentionally be involved with any efforts to impede the objective of the other creature.

The target sees the terms of the contract in their mind and can then choose to accept or decline the contract. If the creature declines the contract, the spell fails to cast and the spell slot is not expended. The spell automatically fails if the target is already under the effects of a spell that controls their actions (such as {@spell suggestion} or this spell).

If the creature accepts the contract, a runic mark is burned into their palm which lasts for the duration of the spell. Then, if either creature fails one of their objectives, that creature must succeed on a Charisma saving throw, which it makes with disadvantage, or be subjected to the punishment you chose.

The punishment(s) you choose can do one of two things: control a creature's actions, or cause them to die. If the punishment you chose controls a creature's actions, it can only do so for up to 1 hour. If the punishment you chose is death, the creature has a heart attack and instantly dies.

This spell is especially hard to dispel. If the {@spell dispel magic} spell is cast to attempt to remove the effects of this spell, it must be cast using a spell slot at least two levels higher than the spell slot used to cast this spell (up to a maximum of 9th-level) in order to successfully end it.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, there is no maximum amount of days for the objectives—the spell lasts until all of the objectives are complete or until dispelled.

spell.name: Capture Soul

m.text: A crystal or some other magically sensitive object, such as an idol or orb, worth at least 100 gp

entries: You touch a dead creature that has been dead for no longer than 10 days and capture their soul, trapping it within the object used for the material component of this spell. The {@spell raise dead} and {@spell reincarnate} spells can be cast on the object to revive the creature, forming a new body for it as described in the {@i reincarnate} spell in both cases. While the soul remains within the object, days spent do not count against the time limit of resurrection spells.

When you cast this spell, you can instead choose to siphon all of the power from the soul. Instead of being trapped within the object, the soul is completely consumed, and you regain hit points equal to 2d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier. Also, you regain the spell slot used to cast this spell, but the new spell slot is 2nd level.

An object containing a trapped soul can be sold to vendors in cities for 500 gp. It can also be placed in a Soul Battery, which is a machine specifically made to siphon mana from the soul, which generates mana from it over a period of 40 years.

spell.name: Channel Senses

components.m: a bit of bat fur and a drop of fresh water

entries: You channel the senses of a willing creature within range. Choose two senses between sight, hearing, touch, smell, and taste. For the duration, you lose the chosen senses and instead receive the senses from the target. You or the target can choose to end the spell at any time for the duration. While channeling a creature's sight, you can cast spells as though you were in the target creature's space, provided the target allows you to do so. Alternatively, you can have the sense be derived from a chosen object and/or have the sense be emitted through a chosen object.

To derive a sense from an object, you must first mark it with a flat sigil, which you can do as an action so long as you have the ability to cast this spell. You can have a number of these sigils active at any time equal to 1 + your spellcasting ability modifier. Sigils glow dim light in a 1-foot radius, are noticed easily, and can be destroyed with little effort.

To emit a sense through an object, you must touch it as a part of casting this spell, and you can only choose the sight or hearing senses when you cast the spell this way. The object then displays a holographic picture or emits audio for the duration, based on your chosen sense.
The range of this spell can be extended through arcane infrastructure. Prismatic Falls has such a setup, allowing this spell to reach to the edges of the city from all locations within it.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can choose an additional sense for every spell level above 1st. Additionally, the spell lasts up to 8 hours.

spell.name: Ethereal Jaunt

m.text: crystals or some other magically sensitive objects worth at least 50 gp, which cover the eyes of the target(s) for the duration

entries: You touch a willing creature, which can be yourself, and project their consciousness towards their soul into the Ethereal Plane, forming an ethereal body surrounding their soul in the area where it overlaps with the current plane. The material body the creature leaves behind is paralyzed and they are unaware of their surroundings for the duration. If you projected your own consciousness, another creature can use its action to snap you out of the trance or signal you to end the spell early.

A creature's ethereal body resembles its mortal form in almost every way, replicating their game statistics and possessions. While in its ethereal body, the creature has the ability to alter their appearance (but not its abilities) to anything they desire.

While in the Ethereal Plane, the creature can move in any direction. If it moves up or down, every foot of movement costs an extra foot. They can see, but not hear, the plane they originated from. Everything within it looks gray, they can't see anything more than 60 feet away, and everything lacks detail; for example, they wouldn't be able to read a book or a sign. Also, they are able to clearly see the souls of creatures on the Material Plane, even through walls, as they reside here on the Ethereal Plane, though they cannot interact with them.

While on the Ethereal Plane, the creature can only affect and be affected by other creatures on that plane. Creatures that aren't on the Ethereal Plane can't perceive them and can't interact with them, unless a special ability or magic has given them the ability to do so. They ignore all objects and effects that aren't on the Ethereal Plane, allowing them to move through objects they perceive on the plane they originated from.

The spell ends early if the creature's ethereal or mortal body drops to 0 hit points. When the spell ends, the creature immediately returns to the plane they originated from and returns to their material body in the location they left it. If their material body is dead and their ethereal body isn't, they instead continue to inhabit their ethereal body in the Ethereal Plane until it is destroyed or they are resurrected.

If you cast this spell in Prismatic Falls, the creature enters soulspace and has a few additional abilities while there. Namely, they can slightly alter the fabric of reality around them, and they gain the ability to {@variantrule 'Hacking' the Material|ccg|pierce the veil} back into the Material Plane.
This spell has no effect if you cast it while on the Ethereal Plane or a plane that doesn't border it.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you can target up to eight willing creatures (including you), to be affected by the spell. The creatures must be within 10 feet of you when you cast the spell.

spell.name: Imbue Knowledge

m.text: a small orb or some other magically sensitive object worth at least 10 gp

entries: You place a memory, idea, message, or image from your mind into the object used for the material component of this spell. The thought must be no longer than the casting time of this spell. A creature can touch the object and use its action to receive the thought.
When you cast this spell, you can also set a password for the object. If you do, the thoughts inside the object can't be viewed unless the password is spoken by the creature while it touches it.

spell.name: Inscribe
entries: This spell inscribes a runic message on a surface you touch, which glows dimly in a 1-foot radius. The message can be 25 words or less. If multiple messages created by different casters are inscribed within 5 feet of each other, they each appear as distinctly different colors, one for each caster. When you inscribe a message, you can choose for it to be visible in either the Material Plane or Ethereal Plane. Also, you can choose for it to be hidden. If you do, the message is invisible to all creatures except for those who know this spell.

spell.name: Mute
entries: You touch a creature or object of medium size or smaller, {@condition muted|ccg|muting} the target for the duration. If the target is a creature and is unwilling, it can make a Constitution saving throw to avoid this effect. A muted target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

No sound can be created by the target or objects they wear or carry, so long as the origin of the sound is within 10 feet of them. Also, if the target is a creature, you choose one of the following additional effects when you cast the spell: (1) the target can't cast spells that require verbal components, or (2) when the target casts a spell, it can cast it without any verbal components, and any spell they cast produces no sound.

spell.name: Search
entries: You speak aloud a single question, channeling the collective knowledge of all creatures within the surrounding region. A ghostly assistant appears before you and verbally gives you an answer to the question, before disappearing shortly afterward.

The answer you receive is drawn from the general information that is commonly known by creatures within 1 mile. If there is no commonly known answer, your search returns no results, and the orb does not appear. If you cast this spell in a more populated environment, such as in a large city, it is more likely to return a result.

If the question you asked is of a contended topic with multiple different answers, the orb will return you up to three of those answers, but not the commonality of each. Your search ignores any answers that are commonly considered to be a secret by those that know it.

spell.name: Soul Bind
entries: You strengthen yourself with powerful spiritual energy. The first time you deal force, radiant, or necrotic damage to a creature during this spell's duration, you bind the soul of one creature you damaged, affecting the target in one of the following ways of your choice:

items: The target takes an extra {@damage 3d6} damage and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the spell ends.
The target takes an extra {@damage 2d6} damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} until the spell ends.
The target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage and must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the spell ends.

entries: Regardless of the effect you choose, an affected target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the extra damage dealt increases by {@damage 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Soul Rend
entries: You empower yourself with spiritual energy. The first time you deal force, radiant, or necrotic damage to a creature during this spell's duration, you tear at the soul of one creature you damaged, dealing an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to the target. Also, you affect the target in one of the following ways of your choice:

items: The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

The target must succeed a Strength saving throw or you move them up to 15 feet in any direction of your choice, except upward. Once they reach their destination, you can also knock them {@condition prone}.
The extra damage dealt increases by {@damage 1d6}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can choose an additional effect for each slot level above 1st. You cannot choose the last effect more than once.

spell.name: Spectral Barrage
entries: A devastating blast of spiritual energy erupts from your soul in a direction of your choice, forming a line 60 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 2d12} force, radiant, or necrotic damage (your choice) and is pushed 10 feet away from you. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@damage 1d12} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Stasis

m.text: a small chunk of iron worth at least 50 gp, which the spell consumes if cast over 1 hour

entries: This spell locks a target in stasis, preventing it from moving. There are two possible uses for this spell—granting either immediate or long-term benefits.

If you cast this spell using 1 action, choose a creature or object within range that is large or smaller. If you target a creature or an object held or worn by one, they must succeed on a Strength saving throw to resist the spell. On a failure, a target can't move until the end of your next turn, even if it is defying gravity. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition incapacitated} until then. Any momentum the target had is maintained while in the spell, and while in stasis, all forces, except gravity, are applied to the target as momentum. When the spell ends, the target is flung in an appropriate direction based on the attacks that hit it and the forces applied to it during the spell. For each attack hit, a creature is flung 10 feet in a straight line. If you cast the spell this way, you can end the spell at any time (no action required from you).

If you cast this spell over 1 hour, choose an object within range that is large or smaller. The object becomes magically fixed in place for 1 year. It doesn't move, even if it is defying gravity. The object can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight—if it holds more, the forces applying to it, such as gravity, begin to apply as normal.

When using either use of this spell, the stasis is relative to the center of the planet—applying the spell to a target within a moving object will cause it to stop in place for the duration, rather than stop above that moving object.

trait.name: Terror Form
entries: The lurker shares the effects of its summoner's {@subclassFeature Incarnation of Fear|Sorcerer||Nightmare|ccg|1||current incarnations}. It gains no benefit from the extra spells.

action.name: Void Slash
entries: {@atk mw} Summoner's attack modifier to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h} {@damage 1d8} + summoner's proficiency bonus necrotic damage. This attack requires the use of its summoner's bonus action.

optionalfeature.name: Boost
entries: The weapon projects an echoing burst, dealing thunder damage. Immediately before or after making the attack, your weapon emits a jet that propels you up to 15 feet in a direction of your choosing. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.

optionalfeature.name: Bounce
entries: The weapon unleashes a propelling blast, dealing force damage. On a hit, a target must make a Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet in a direction of your choosing, except upwards or towards you. The target automatically succeeds on the save if it is more than one size larger than you.

optionalfeature.name: Burn
entries: The weapon ignites, dealing fire damage. On a hit, choose a different creature within 10 feet of the original target. It takes fire damage equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Chill
entries: The weapon chills your target, dealing cold damage. On a hit, a target must make a Constitution saving throw or have their speed reduced to 0 until the end of their next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Cloak
entries: The weapon is coated in darkness, dealing necrotic damage. Immediately after making the attack, you become {@condition invisible} until the end of your next turn. The invisibility ends early if you make an attack or cast a spell.

optionalfeature.name: Confuse
entries: The weapon is imbued with bizarre energy, dealing psychic damage. On a hit, a target must make a Wisdom saving throw or use all of their movement to move in a random direction at the start of their next turn. Roll a {@dice d8} and assign a direction to each dice face.

optionalfeature.name: Heal
entries: The weapon is infused with holy energy, dealing radiant damage. Hit or miss, one creature of your choice, other than you, regains a number of hit points equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier. The creature must be within 5 feet of you or within 5 feet of the target of the attack.

optionalfeature.name: Horrify
entries: The weapon emits a terrifying screech, dealing psychic damage. On a hit, a target must make a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Infect
entries: The weapon infects the target with venom, dealing poison damage. On a hit, a target must make a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of their next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Manifest
entries: The weapon manifests a mystical power, dealing force damage. Hit or miss, you choose an empty space within 30 feet of you to create a wall of pure magic that lasts for the next minute. The wall is a 5 foot by 10 foot panel that is 6 inches thick, and you can place it in any orientation—meaning it can act as a platform. The wall can float in mid air, ignoring gravity, and it can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight. Lastly, the wall has an AC and a number of hit points equal to your Intelligence Score.

optionalfeature.name: Melt
entries: The weapon melts the target's armor, dealing acid damage. On a hit, the target's AC is reduced by an amount equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of 1 AC reduced) until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Neutralize
entries: The weapon strikes with an electrifying aftershock, dealing lightning damage. On a hit, a target must make a Constitution saving throw or be unable to cast spells or use magic items until the end of their next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Project (Melee Only)
entries: The weapon is charged with glowing energy, emitting powerful rays that deal radiant damage. Your reach for the attack increases to 60 feet. Additionally, any other melee attacks you make with the weapon on this turn also deal radiant damage and benefit from the range increase.

optionalfeature.name: Pull (Melee Only)
entries: The weapon is coated with magnetic energy, dealing lightning damage. Immediately before making the attack, you can choose one target within 30 feet of you that is no more than one size larger than you. It must make a Strength saving throw or be pulled towards you until it is within 5 feet of you.

optionalfeature.name: Safeguard
entries: The weapon pulses with protective energy, dealing radiant damage. Hit or miss, you gain temporary hit points equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Scope (Ranged Only)
entries: The weapon morphs and sparks, dealing lightning damage. Your range for the attack is doubled, you ignore half and three-quarters cover for the attack, you don't suffer disadvantage on the attack roll as a result of being prone.

optionalfeature.name: Seek (Ranged Only)
entries: The weapon locks onto your target and curves to seek them, firing bolts that deal force damage. If you have seen your target within the last minute, you can attack them even if you can't see them, and you don't suffer disadvantage on the attack roll if the target is invisible. Your attack travels freely around corners or through openings to reach your target. You also ignore half cover and three-quarters cover for this attack.

optionalfeature.name: Arm Augmentation
entries: You gain proficiency in all {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon}. Also, you can use either of your free hands as evolutionary weapons.

optionalfeature.name: Core Augmentation
entries: Your hit point maximum increases by an amount equal to your evolutionist level and it increases by 1 again each time you gain a level in this class.

optionalfeature.name: Exterior Augmentation
entries: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 13 + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

optionalfeature.name: Growth Augmentation
entries: You gain up to four new bodily features which can be used as evolutionary weapons. These new features can't use items or wield weapons or shields.

optionalfeature.name: Head Augmentation
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill and one other skill of your choice.

optionalfeature.name: Leg Augmentation
entries: Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Amorphous
entries: Your form bends and contorts. You can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there, and you can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

optionalfeature.name: Aquatic
entries: You can breathe in water and air. Also, you gain a swimming speed of 30 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Bigger and Better
entries: You enhance one of your evolutionary weapons, or you weaponize your entire body, turning it into a new evolutionary weapon. If you use Strength for this evolutionary weapon's attack and damage rolls, its damage die increases to {@damage 2d6}.

optionalfeature.name: Breaking Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack while {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignited}, you can cripple their defenses. The next attack roll made by a creature other than you against the target has advantage, provided it is made before the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Crafted Critter
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you create a small critter to aid you, which lasts until it dies or until you activate this upgrade again. Choose a {@filter CR 0 beast|bestiary|Challenge Rating=[&0]|type=beast} that you have seen before. The critter takes its form and statistics, though it is a construct (Innovation), monstrosity (Mutation) or aberration (Infusion) instead of a beast. It obeys your commands to the best of its ability (no action required from you). In combat, the critter shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours.

optionalfeature.name: Crippling Blows
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can halve the target's speed until the end of your next turn. Until then, the target's speed can't be reduced this way again.

optionalfeature.name: Elemental Cannon
entries: When you activate this upgrade, choose one of your evolutionary weapons, and choose a damage type between cold, fire, or lightning. You can use the evolutionary weapon to make ranged weapon attacks that do damage of the chosen damage type. It has a normal range of 30 feet and a long range of 120 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Energy Burst
entries: As an action, you can suffer the hit point reduction of your {@classFeature Metabolic Ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3} to emit a burst of energy in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes cold, fire or lightning damage (your choice) equal to {@damage 2d10} + your evolutionist level on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. After you take this action, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Fiery Aura
entries: When you first {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignited} and at the start of each of your turns thereafter while you remain ignited, you can choose to emit a burst of flames, dealing fire damage to all other creatures within 10 feet of you. This damage equals your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1).

optionalfeature.name: Flight
entries: You gain a flying speed of 30 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Freezing Aura
entries: While {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignited}, you can choose to emit an aura of frost in a 10-foot radius around you. This area counts as difficult terrain, and other creatures inside can't take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Dash} actions.

optionalfeature.name: Frightening Revival
entries: When a creature deals damage that reduces you to 0 hit points and you use your {@classFeature Undying|evolutionist|ccg|3} feature to instead remain at 1 hit point, you can use your reaction to have them make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, they are {@condition Frightened} of you until the end of their next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Micromagic Engine
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you learn {@filter two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list|spells|level=0|class=Wizard}. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these cantrips.

optionalfeature.name: Noxious Aura
entries: While {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignited}, you can choose to emit a toxic cloud in a 10-foot radius around you. Each creature, other than you, that starts its turn in the area must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, they are {@condition poisoned} until the start of their next turn. On a successful saving throw, a creature is immune to your stench for 1 hour.

optionalfeature.name: Overwhelming Impact
entries: When you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can push the target up to 5 feet away in any direction, except upward.

optionalfeature.name: Pathfinder
entries: You gain a climbing speed of 30 feet. Also, your weapon attacks deal double damage to objects and structures.

optionalfeature.name: Skill Versatility
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can choose a skill you lack proficiency in. You gain proficiency in it until you choose a new one through this upgrade.

optionalfeature.name: Tether Strike
entries: You gain a new evolutionary weapon that takes the form of a chain or powerful wire. You make ranged attacks rather than melee attacks with the weapon, it has a range of 20 feet, and its damage dice is a d6 rather than a d10. When you hit a creature or object with the weapon, you can choose to move yourself in a straight line until you are within 5 feet of the target. Alternatively, if the target is no more than one size larger than you, you can have the target make a Strength saving throw. On a failure, they are pulled in a straight line until they are within 5 feet of you.

optionalfeature.name: Brawler
entries: You enhance your fists. After you make two melee attacks against the same creature with your arm evolutionary weapons in one turn, you can force the target to make a Strength saving throw. On a failure, the target is {@condition grappled} by you. If the target is too large for you to grapple or already grappled by you, they are instead knocked {@condition prone}.

optionalfeature.name: Double Jointed
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks and any ability checks you make with {@item thieves' tools|ccg}.

optionalfeature.name: Integrated Crusher
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can {@variantrule Integrated Items|ccg|integrate} a {@filter melee weapon with the two-handed property|items|type=melee weapon|property=two-handed} into one of your arms. If you score a critical hit with the weapon while it is integrated this way, the target is {@condition dazed|ccg} until the end of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Integrated Defender
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can {@variantrule Integrated Items|ccg|integrate} a {@filter shield|items|type=shield} into one of your arms. If you're hit with an attack or subject to damage from an effect that required you to make a Dexterity or Strength saving throw while you have it extended, you can use your reaction to reduce the damage dealt by an amount equal to your evolutionist level.

optionalfeature.name: Integrated Duelist
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can {@variantrule Integrated Items|ccg|integrate} a {@filter melee weapon that lacks the two-handed or special properties|items|type=melee weapon|property=!special;!two-handed} into one of your arms. When you do, choose one of the following properties: light, reach, or thrown (20/60). The weapon gains the property if it doesn't already have it. If you choose the thrown property, you can return the weapon to you immediately after you make a thrown attack with it, provided it is within 60 feet of you (no action required).

optionalfeature.name: Integrated Marksman
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can {@variantrule Integrated Items|ccg|integrate} a {@filter ranged weapon|items|type=range} into one of your arms. While a weapon is integrated this way, you ignore its loading property if it has it, and you also ignore any ability score requirements it has. Additionally, when you hit a creature with it, you can push the creature up to 10 feet away from you in a straight line.

optionalfeature.name: Adrenal Control
entries: When you {@classFeature metabolic ignition|evolutionist|ccg|3||ignite}, you can choose to also increase your adrenaline flow for 1 minute. Once on each of your turns during that time, you can add {@damage 1d8} to one attack roll you make. You must choose to do so before you make the roll. Once you increase your adrenaline flow this way, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Auto-Injector
entries: You upgrade yourself with an automatic injector. As an action, you can fit a potion or narcotic in the injector. While an item is fitted inside, you can consume it as a bonus action rather than as an action. Additionally, when you activate this upgrade or after you finish a long rest, you can create one {@item potion of greater healing||Greater Potion of Healing} or one random, uncommon {@item arcane narcotic (uncommon)|ccg|Arcane Narcotic}, which you can choose to be already fitted into your injector. The created item lasts until you create another with this upgrade, you can't create another until you finish a long rest, and only you can use it.

optionalfeature.name: Mimicry
entries: You can mimic sounds you have heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds you make can tell they are imitations with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check opposed by your Upgrade save DC.

optionalfeature.name: Super Strength
entries: You have advantage on all Strength checks. Also, you can now attempt to {@action grapple} and {@action shove} creatures up to two sizes larger than you, rather than one.

optionalfeature.name: Transfer Vitality
entries: As an action, you can touch a creature and choose an amount of hit points up to your evolutionist level. Your current hit points are reduced by the chosen amount, then the chosen creature regains the same amount of hit points, plus an amount equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1). After you take this action, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: True Survivor
entries: You are immune to disease and the {@condition poisoned} condition. You no longer need to breathe, and you are immune to the effects of extreme cold and heat. Additionally, you count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

optionalfeature.name: Barbed Skin
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with an attack or starts their turn while {@condition grappled} by you or grappling you, you can use your reaction to deal piercing damage to them equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1).

optionalfeature.name: Chameleonic
entries: You can change the coloration of your body at will, granting you advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.

optionalfeature.name: Pheremones
entries: You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks against creatures within 10 feet of you, provided they have a sense of smell.

optionalfeature.name: Provoking Façade
entries: Creatures within 5 feet of you that can see you have disadvantage on any attack roll that isn't against you.

optionalfeature.name: Shifting Form
entries: You can use your action to change your appearance. You decide what you look like, including your height, weight, facial features, sound of your voice, hair length, coloration, and distinguishing characteristics, if any. Your size and basic shape must stay the same, and none of your statistics change.

optionalfeature.name: Terrifying Form
entries: You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks against creatures that can see you.

optionalfeature.name: Extra Appendages
entries: You turn any amount of your evolutionary weapons into extra appendages that have the ability to hold and use items and weapons, provided they {@filter don't have the two-handed property or are a shield|items|type=!shield|property=!two-handed}. Each of these allow you to interact with an additional object or feature of the environment for free during your turn, and you can also now initiate {@action grapple||grapples} with them. While any of these appendages are holding a weapon, you can't gain the benefit of a shield.

optionalfeature.name: Fused Weapon
entries: When you activate this upgrade, you can choose a {@filter magical melee weapon|items|type=melee weapon|miscellaneous=magic}, infusing it into one of your evolutionary weapons. Until you activate this upgrade again, the evolutionary weapon gains the magical weapon's properties, including attunement, though the damage die of the evolutionary weapon remains the same.

optionalfeature.name: Long Reach Weapon
entries: Your evolutionary weapons gain a reach of 10 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Maneuvering Appendages
entries: Your new bodily features take a form that assists you with your movement, such as extra legs or a tail. Your walking speed increases by 10 feet, and when you {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage}, you also gain the benefits of the other action.

optionalfeature.name: Retaliating Weapons
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to make an attack with one of your evolutionary weapons against that creature, provided they are within range. On a hit, this attack does no damage and instead, the creature is knocked {@condition prone}.

optionalfeature.name: Whirling Weapons
entries: You can use your action to make a melee attack with one of your evolutionary weapons against any number of creatures within reach, with a separate attack roll for each target.

optionalfeature.name: Dead-eye
entries: Your ranged attacks ignore half and three-quarters cover and don't have disadvantage against creatures who are {@condition prone}. Also, the range of your ranged attacks is doubled.

optionalfeature.name: Enhanced Mind
entries: You enhance your mind and your reflexes. You gain resistance to psychic damage. Also, when you make a saving throw with any ability other than Strength or Constitution or when you make an attack roll as a part of an opportunity attack, you can use this upgrade to gain a bonus to the roll equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1). You can gain this bonus twice, regaining expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Enhanced Vision
entries: You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight and gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet if you don't already have it.

optionalfeature.name: Otherworldly Vision
entries: You have {@sense blindsight} out to 10 feet and you can see into the Ethereal Plane out to 60 feet. Ethereal creatures and objects appear ghostly and translucent.

optionalfeature.name: Thermal Sight
entries: You can see creatures and moving objects through walls, so long as they are not behind more than a total of 1 foot of material or {@condition invisible}. To you, these creatures appear as a colored-silhouette.

optionalfeature.name: Tracker
entries: You enhance your smell and hearing. You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell and Wisdom ({@skill Survival} or {@skill Navigation|ccg}) checks made to track creatures.

optionalfeature.name: Acceptance (Serenity)
entries: Your spiritual powers awakened from pure acceptance, leading you to the path of tranquility. Whenever a creature within 30 feet of you takes damage during your {@classFeature soul surge|soulshaper|ccg|3}, you can choose to reduce it by an amount equal to your proficiency bonus. Also, you gain a flying speed of 30 feet during your soul surge.

optionalfeature.name: Fear (Preservation)
entries: Your spiritual powers awakened from your fear, leading you to focus on preserving what's left. When you {@classFeature soul surge|soulshaper|ccg|3}, you gain temporary hit points equal to 2d10 + your soulshaper level. Also, during your soul surge, you and creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you don't provoke opportunity attacks.

optionalfeature.name: Grief (Love)
entries: Your spiritual powers awakened when you lost someone you cared for, leading you to now protect those you can. When you {@classFeature soul surge|soulshaper|ccg|3}, healing energy erupts from you, allowing you to restore a number of hit points equal to 3d10 + your soulshaper level. Choose creatures within 30 feet of you and distribute the hit points among the chosen creatures as you like.

optionalfeature.name: Hate (Retribution)
entries: Your spiritual powers awakened out of anger and hatred, leading you to bring justice to those who deserve it. Up to two times during your {@classFeature soul surge|soulshaper|ccg|3}, when you or a creature within 30 feet of you takes damage from an attack, you can use your reaction to force the attacker to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes force, radiant, or necrotic damage (your choice) equal to the damage it just dealt and is {@condition frightened} of the creature it damaged until the end of its next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Regret (Ambition)
entries: Your spiritual powers were awakened by your regrets, leading you to make the most of this new opportunity you've been gifted. During your {@classFeature soul surge|soulshaper|ccg|3}, you have advantage on attack rolls. Also, when you enter your soul surge, you can choose one other creature within 30 feet of you. They also have advantage on attack rolls while they remain within 30 feet of you for the duration.

optionalfeature.name: Crowd Clearer
entries: When you use the special attack of a {@filter spread weapon|items|property=spread}, creatures take half as much damage on a successful save, rather than none. This does not count as a hit weapon attack against those creatures.

Additionally, the area of the special attacks you make with spread weapons is increased: pierce's line is now 5-foot wide, burst is now a 15-foot cube, erupt is now a 20 foot cone, and cleave is now all creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you.

optionalfeature.name: Deflection
entries: When a creature you can see attacks you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on the attack roll, attempting to parry the strike. You must be wielding {@filter a weapon with the defender property|items|property=defender} to use this reaction.

optionalfeature.name: Resourceful
entries: You ignore the ability score requirements for all weapons you are proficient in. Also, you gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls with all weapons that don't already benefit from a Fighting Style you have.

optionalfeature.name: Skirmisher
entries: After you make a weapon attack against a creature further than 5 feet away from you, your movement speed increases by 10 feet until the end of the turn. Additionally, you can add your proficiency bonus to your initiative rolls.

skill.name: Navigation
entries: Wisdom (Navigation) governs one's ability to track monsters, beasts, or people, as well as find the best path for a group through an area, such as shortcuts through the streets or through more dangerous areas such as a frozen wasteland.
{@note This skill replaces {@skill Survival} as part of the variant rule {@variantrule Skill Replacements and Adjustments for Crystalpunk|ccg}.}

skill.name: Streetwise
entries: As a GM, you might ask your players to make a Wisdom (Streetwise) check to gather information, intuit information related to gangs, reputations, rivalries, events, or crime in the immediate area, conjure a false identity that can bypass scrutiny, or attempt to gain access to exclusive areas such as clubs or criminal hideouts.
{@note This skill replaces {@skill Animal Handling} as part of the variant rule {@variantrule Skill Replacements and Adjustments for Crystalpunk|ccg}.}

table.name: Narcotic Properties
rows: {@b Adrenaline.} You have advantage on Athletics and Acrobatics checks for 1 hour.
{@b Agility.} You gain a +1 bonus to AC and have advantage on initiative rolls for 8 hours.
{@b Awareness.} You have advantage on {@skill Perception}, {@skill Insight}, and {@skill Investigation} checks for 1 hour.
{@b Confidence.} You have advantage on all Charisma checks for 1 hour.
{@b Healing.} You regain {@dice 3d12} hit points. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Infusion.} You regain one expended spell slot of 3rd-level or lower. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Numbness.} You have advantage on Constitution saving throws for 8 hours.

{@b Potency.} Roll 2d6 to determine two random ability scores, re-rolling duplicates. Choose one of the results, which becomes 19 for you for the next 8 hours if that score of yours is not already 19 or higher.
{@b Swiftness.} Your walking speed is increased by 30 feet for 1 hour.
{@b Visions.} For the next 8 hours, you can cast the {@spell augury} and {@spell see invisibility} spells at will.

table.name: Narcotic Side Effects
rows: {@b Shaky.} For the next hour, whenever you make a saving throw that you don't have advantage on, you must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the result.
{@b Fatigued.} For the next hour, whenever you make an ability check that you don't have advantage on, you must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the result.
{@b Scorched.} You take {@damage 1d12} necrotic damage, which can't be reduced in any way. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Lethargic.} You have disadvantage on Initiative rolls for the next 8 hours.
{@b Loud.} You have disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks for the next hour.
{@b Sluggish.} Your walking speed is decreased by 10 feet for the next hour.

variantrule.name: Armored Defense
entries: When using the Unarmored Defense feature from the {@class barbarian} or {@class monk} classes, you can flavor the feature as wearing a mechanical suit of armor. This does not count as wearing armor for you, but only your character should be able to use the armor.

variantrule.name: Optional Class Features for Crystalpunk
entries: The following optional class features are intended for use with characters in the Crystalpunk world.

entries.name: Shotgun Slayer
entries: {@i Optional 1st-level barbarian feature}

You can use Strength rather than Dexterity for the attack and damage rolls of ranged weapons you are proficient in, provided you make the attack against a target within 20 feet of you. If you make a ranged attack using Strength this way, it receives the benefits of your {@classFeature Rage|barbarian||1} and {@classFeature Brutal Critical (1 die)|barbarian||9||Brutal Critical } features as if it was a melee weapon. It is also eligible for the advantage granted by your {@classFeature Reckless Attack|barbarian||2}, provided that the attack is made against a target within 5 feet of you.
If you take this optional feature, your barbarian hit die is reduced to a d10, which reduces your hit points at 1st level and at higher levels to that of the fighter class.

entries.name: Holy Sniper
entries: {@i Optional 1st-level paladin feature}
At 2nd level when you choose your {@classFeature Fighting Style|paladin||2}, {@optfeature Archery} is added to your available options.

Also, you can now only use your {@classFeature Divine Smite|Paladin||2} feature with ranged weapon attacks, rather than with melee weapon attacks. The extra radiant damage dealt when you use the feature is also adjusted—it is now {@damage 2d6} for a 1st-level spell slot, plus {@damage 1d6} for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of {@damage 5d6}. The damage increases by {@damage 1d6} if the target is an undead or a fiend, to a maximum of {@damage 6d6}.

Additionally, when you reach 11th level, your {@classFeature Improved Divine Smite|Paladin||11} feature now only deals its extra radiant damage on ranged weapon attacks, rather than on melee weapon attacks, and the extra damage radiant damage dealt is adjusted to {@damage 1d6}.

entries.name: Mystic Sight
entries: {@i Optional 3rd-level ranger feature, which replaces the {@classFeature Primeval Awareness|Ranger||3} feature}

At 3rd level, you learn an additional spell of your choice from any class. The spell you choose must be a {@filter divination spell|spells|school=D} that is of a level you can cast. When you reach 5th, 9th, 13th, and 17th level, you can choose one additional spell for this feature, which must abide by the above prerequisites. These spells count as ranger spells for you, but don't count against the number of ranger spells you know.
You can cast each of the spells you learn with this feature once without expending a spell slot. Once you cast a spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Urban Explorer
entries: {@i Optional 1st-level ranger feature}

When choosing a favored terrain for your {@classFeature Natural Explorer|Ranger||1} feature, High-Rises, Streets, and Slums are added to your available options. These new options represent the various altitudes of the city of Prismatic Falls—with the High-Rises at the top, and the Slums at the bottom.

variantrule.name: 'Hacking' the Material
entries: {@note The below is taken from {@variantrule Soulspace|ccg} for quick reference.}
Affecting the material world while in the Ethereal Plane is normally impossible, but as the border to the Ethereal Plane is so weak in Prismatic Falls, it is possible, albeit difficult.

While in Soulspace, a creature can attempt to pierce the ethereal veil—making an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) or Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check against a DC that is based on the intensity of magic where they are trying to pierce into, where more intense is easier. On a success, they pierce into the Material Plane for a brief period, able to interact with their surroundings for the next 5 minutes. On a failure, they take {@damage 2d6} psychic damage. In either case, they cannot attempt to pierce the veil again for the next hour.

During those 5 minutes, a creature can interact with the Material Plane as if they were on it, though they appear as a ghostly figure and any objects they take do not come back with them. This usually gives them enough time to cast a few spells, attempt to pick a lock, read some secret documents, or retrieve some secret information from objects that have had the {@spell imbue knowledge|ccg} spell cast on them. Certain adept agents—called Runners—are specially trained to be ethereal scouts in Soulspace using this method, gathering information and aiding allies in the real world wherever they can.

There are many defenses used against this method. Mercenaries called Seekers and Phantoms are used as well as spells such as {@spell Mordenkainen's Private Sanctum||Private Sanctum}, which stops creatures from piercing the veil in that area. The most secure locations in Prismatic Falls have such ethereal defenses, and they are tough to break through with this method.

variantrule.name: Crystalpunk Background Options
entries: This section provides futuristic backgrounds for Crystalpunk characters, intended to be used in place of other preexisting options. Each one provides proficiencies, languages, and equipment. Some of these backgrounds also optionally provide spells in the place of other proficiencies, which is explained below.

entries.name: Background Cantrips
entries: Many of the new backgrounds provide one or more cantrips. A character can choose to learn up to two of the listed cantrips by sacrificing one of the skill proficiencies granted by the background for each. The spellcasting ability for these cantrips is the same as the character's Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature, and is otherwise Intelligence if the character does not have either of those features.

entries.name: Background Spells
entries: Many of the new backgrounds also provide one or more spells of 1st-level or higher. If a character has the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature or will later attain either, they can choose to gain up to two of those spells by sacrificing one of the language or tool proficiencies granted by the background for each. If they do, the spells are added to one of their classes' spell lists. If a spell gained this way is already on one of those spell lists, the character instead learns that spell and it is always prepared for them.

entries.name: Background Gear Packs
entries: The provided backgrounds grant {@filter Gear Packs|items|type=regular gear pack;tool gear pack}, which takes the place of equipment. Each character also gains a set of {@item Casual Gear|ccg} upon choosing any of these backgrounds.

variantrule.name: Background Cantrips
entries: {@note The below is taken from {@variantrule Crystalpunk Background Options|ccg} for quick reference.}

Many of the new backgrounds provide one or more cantrips. A character can choose to learn up to two of the listed cantrips by sacrificing one of the skill proficiencies granted by the background for each. The spellcasting ability for these cantrips is the same as the character's Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature, and is otherwise Intelligence if the character does not have either of those features.

variantrule.name: Background Spells
entries: {@note The below is taken from {@variantrule Crystalpunk Background Options|ccg} for quick reference.}

Many of the new backgrounds also provide one or more spells of 1st-level or higher. If a character has the Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature or will later attain either, they can choose to gain up to two of those spells by sacrificing one of the language or tool proficiencies granted by the background for each. If they do, the spells are added to one of their classes' spell lists. If a spell gained this way is already on one of those spell lists, the character instead learns that spell and it is always prepared for them.

variantrule.name: Skill Replacements and Adjustments for Crystalpunk
entries: Here are some replacements and adjustments to the skills of the game, intended to adapt the game to urban environments. The skill replacements change each skill entirely, while the adjustments add a few more scenarios where each skill may be used.

entries.name: Skill Replacements
entries: {@b {@skill Survival}} is replaced with {@b Wisdom ({@skill Navigation|ccg})}, which governs one's ability to track monsters, beasts, or people, as well as find the best path for a group through an area, such as shortcuts through the streets or through more dangerous areas such as a frozen wasteland.

{@b {@skill Animal Handling}} is replaced with {@b Wisdom ({@skill Streetwise|ccg})}, which determines one's experience with urban areas and their ability to act within their unwritten rules. As a GM, you might ask your players to make a Wisdom (Streetwise) check to gather information, intuit information related to gangs, reputations, rivalries, events, or crime in the immediate area, conjure a false identity that can bypass scrutiny, or attempt to gain access to exclusive areas such as clubs or criminal hideouts. In cases where you would previously call for a Wisdom (Animal Handling) check, you can instead call for a Wisdom ({@skill Nature}) check.

entries.name: Skill Adjustments
entries: {@b {@skill Arcana}} now includes information related to magical technology and how it functions.
{@b {@skill History}} now includes general knowledge, as well as information related to military, logistics, economics, and politics.
{@b {@skill Nature}} now includes information related to geography, biology, food, poisons, and narcotics.
{@b {@skill Religion}} now includes information related to the cults of Prismatic Falls and their activities.

{@b {@skill Intimidation}} now includes attempting to keep your cool when threatened. For example, when two characters confront each other, you can have them make a contested Charisma (Intimidation) check to see who backs down first.

variantrule.name: Soulspace
entries: Throughout the entirety of the gargantuan Prismatic Falls lies a parallel world hidden to the naked eye—a world with the same structures, but bathed in an ethereal gray, where the souls of all those in Prismatic Falls can be seen clearly. This is Soulspace—a name given to the section of the Ethereal Plane that lies over Prismatic Falls. It is a tangential dimension where richer citizens in Prismatic Falls go to live second lives, make secret deals, and entertain themselves. In Soulspace, the concepts of material and thought converge; allowing those inside to alter their appearances entirely and subtly affect the ethereal world around them using their imaginations.

entries.name: Entering Soulspace
entries: In Prismatic Falls, Soulspace is accessed through the {@spell ethereal jaunt|ccg} spell. Regular citizens access this spell through Manateks or through Autospells that exist with locations called Ether Centres, which are stores that sell the casting of ethereal jaunt. The spell usually costs around 100 gp, and lasts for up to 4 hours.

The souls of those on the Material Plane exist within Soulspace in the same location as they are in the material. You normally can't interact with these souls within Soulspace, though some specialized agents have trained to do so (see the {@class warlock||Lost Soul|Lost Soul|ccg} warlock patron).

entries.name: Second Lives
entries: In Soulspace, one can move around the space freely—gravity does not exist in Soulspace, and those inside move around using their force of will. In addition to that, those in Soulspace can freely {@b alter their own appearance} (but not their abilities) using their imaginations, allowing anyone to be an anonymous member of this parallel community. Many take on alter egos and vibrant personas, creating a new person to live as; living out fantastical lives that they simply could not in the real world.

entries.name: Ethereal Structures
entries: In addition to altering appearances, the very fabric of reality can be altered with one's imagination. While the effect is quite small for only one person, many people can, and have, come together to make grand structures purely out of their imaginations—which even includes color and moving objects, normally not present in the plane. This has transformed Soulspace into a vibrant community of extravagant artwork, interactive games, and grand structures; all created by the efforts of an anonymous community and existing on top of the already present locations and buildings projected up from Prismatic Falls. Here are some structures you might find:

rows: {@b The Museum.} A grand, cylindrical, museum that stretches upwards into the sky, each layer hosting a uniquely crafted art piece.
{@b The Haven.} A tranquil land of lush greenery and wildlife where many go to relax.
{@b The Grand Challenges.} An obstacle course on ground level, including hoops to fly through, ramps to slide down, and ropes to swing across.
{@b The Arena.} A large arena equipped with ethereal weaponry, where you can spar opponents without any harm or play a variety of sports.
{@b The Kitchen.} A market with specially imagined pots that allows objects to garner taste in Soulspace, where you can try wholly unique flavors.
{@b The Studio.} A large, box-like building that hosts many different rooms. Each room has the power to draw music from the soul and amplify it.
{@b The Outpost.} An outpost at the edge of the city where citizens with large nets attempt to catch stray thoughts; stories told by those in Soulspace and old tales from ancient ghosts.
{@b The Forum.} A large set of message boards where many leave messages and markings, often having conversations. Some use the Inscribe spell to leave messages here.

entries: There are, however, threats to this community—groups of anonymous citizens who aim to tear down the ethereal structures in Soulspace, coming together to destroy what was made. These ethereal terrorists have varied motivations and are often hated by many who live much of their lives within Soulspace.

entries.name: Secret Deals
entries: With Soulspace allowing complete anonymity, many secret deals are made within it, with each participant going to a set location marked on the Material Plane. The {@spell inscribe|ccg} spell is also sometimes used in these deals, to mark some writing in a hidden location, where another will come to find it later. These messages can also be set to be viewed in the Material Plane.

entries.name: Action in Soulspace
entries: While in Soulspace, one's features are mimicked within the plane—they are able to fight and cast spells as usual, and their hit points function as normal. (though they float around instead of walking). Some of their physical abilities, however, are bound by their mental fortitude. Whenever a creature in Soulspace makes an ability check or saving throw using Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution, they use their highest ability modifier out of Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma instead.

entries.name: 'Hacking' the Material
entries: Affecting the material world while in the Ethereal Plane is normally impossible, but as the border to the Ethereal Plane is so weak in Prismatic Falls, it is possible, albeit difficult.

While in Soulspace, a creature can attempt to pierce the ethereal veil—making an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) or Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check against a DC that is based on the intensity of magic where they are trying to pierce into, where more intense is easier. On a success, they pierce into the Material Plane for a brief period, able to interact with their surroundings for the next 5 minutes. On a failure, they take {@damage 2d6} psychic damage. In either case, they cannot attempt to pierce the veil again for the next hour.

During those 5 minutes, a creature can interact with the Material Plane as if they were on it, though they appear as a ghostly figure and any objects they take do not come back with them. This usually gives them enough time to cast a few spells, attempt to pick a lock, read some secret documents, or retrieve some secret information from objects that have had the {@spell imbue knowledge|ccg} spell cast on them. Certain adept agents—called Runners—are specially trained to be ethereal scouts in Soulspace using this method, gathering information and aiding allies in the real world wherever they can.

There are many defenses used against this method. Mercenaries called Seekers and Phantoms are used as well as spells such as {@spell Mordenkainen's Private Sanctum||Private Sanctum}, which stops creatures from piercing the veil in that area. The most secure locations in Prismatic Falls have such ethereal defenses, and they are tough to break through with this method.

entries.name: Threats in Soulspace
entries: There are a few threats in Soulspace. One is ghosts, though they tend to not stray near any of the created structures. Some vengeful ones are still a threat to those within the plane. The second are Ethereal Agents, which is the name given to trained mercenaries that defend material locations against Soulspace and those within it. Those that stay in the Material Plane and see into the ethereal are called Seekers, and those that venture into Soulspace are called Phantoms. For Seekers, use the {@creature Augmented|ccg} stat block (choosing the Otherworldly Vision upgrade for them), and for Phantoms, use the {@creature Street Warrior|ccg} stat block.

entries.name: Living in Soulspace
entries: Some spend so much time in Soulspace that one could say that they live there. The effect on one's body from doing so is brutal—a lack of activity can cause it to deteriorate at a rapid rate, making common extended visits to Soulspace a large health risk. Many take this risk however, as they enjoy themselves much more in Soulspace than on the material. There are even some who purposely let their material bodies die while in the ethereal jaunt spell, allowing them to stay in Soulspace forever.

entries.name: Missions in Soulspace
entries: Missions in Soulspace usually involve intrigue or are a part of a larger endeavor, often a heist, which is taking place at the same time within the Material Plane. Here is a mission example:

{@b Ethereal Revenge.} A {@race nephilim|ccg} named Indigo who is an Ethereal Artist has angered a Kingmaker gang led by a half-elf named Switchblade in the material world. Indigo had made artwork depicting the Kingmaker as brutal barbarians, and the gang retaliated by destroying all of Indigo's artwork in Soulspace. Indigo hires the players to deal with this gang in whatever method they see fit—though the gang's base of operation is a mystery. Indigo knows what Switchblade's avatar looks like in Soulspace, and asks the players to hunt them down in Soulspace to find out where they are hiding.

rows: Today, I was pulled from the set of Rainy Report, and was fired from my job behind the scenes. This show is now my primary focus, and we're working on a plan to better this city in more ways than just arming you with the facts. Today I'm joined by the channel senses vessel of Rainy Report, please welcome Goggles!
Good to see you Reverb. Your viewers know how the producers treated you, I resisted their blindness/deafness a few times towards the end.
Good man. We'll make a Crystalpunk of you yet my friend!

variantrule.name: Vehicles in Crystalpunk
entries: Vehicles are commonplace in the world of Crystalpunk, especially in the city of Prismatic Falls. They come in both land and air varieties; and some models of land vehicles hover slightly above the ground. They are all powered by Infernal Engines, potent devices that siphon energy out of one or more captured fiends, and into the vehicle. While these fiends provide a source of fuel for the vehicle, they also require a new soul every few years to be maintained.

Driving these vehicles is a magical process—arcane crystals within the wheel draw mana and information from the user and feed it to the rest of the vehicle to make it operate. As such, it is fairly intuitive, and most people who live in the cities of Aysta know how to drive a vehicle. However, this doesn't mean they drive them competently. Only by having proficiency in a specific vehicle type is a character adept at handling the vehicle, especially in tough situations.

entries.name: Vehicle Rules
entries: Here are the rules to implement when using vehicles.

entries.name: The Driver
entries: As the driver, the vehicle moves on your initiative, though it should be treated as the vehicle making its move gradually throughout the entire round so as for it to move at a constant rate. You have complete control over the vehicle's speed on your turn, up to its maximum. The vehicle itself cannot {@action Dash} or otherwise take actions. On your turn, you must keep at least one hand on the wheel to continue driving. You can otherwise use your action, bonus action, and reaction as normal.

If you wish to perform more complex maneuvers with your vehicle, such as fast turns, jumps, or sideswipes, you must use your action and have two hands on the wheel. When doing such maneuvers, you must make a Dexterity check, adding your proficiency bonus if you are proficient in the type of vehicle you are driving. The DC and outcome is determined by your GM. You might also have to perform such a check when trying to chase or get away from another vehicle, or as a reaction when your car is put into a dangerous situation to avoid losing control or wiping out.

If you attempt to damage another vehicle through a maneuver, make the check against the opposing vehicle's AC. On a success, you deal bludgeoning damage to the opposing vehicle, if its size category is equal to or less than yours. The damage is equals two rolls of a dice of a size equal to your car's hit dice size, plus your Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Fighting on Vehicles
entries: When fighting while in a vehicle, or fighting a creature on a vehicle, attack rolls are made with disadvantage and creatures have advantage on saving throws against any creature not moving at similar speed. If multiple vehicles are moving next to each other at a similar speed, the creatures in them act in combat as normal, as if they were not moving at all.

entries.name: Getting In and Out
entries: You can enter or exit a vehicle by using half of your movement on your turn. If you are the driver, you can then use your action to have the vehicle begin moving. Otherwise, the vehicle begins moving at the start of your next turn.

If you wish to jump from one vehicle to another while both are moving, you'll need to perform a long jump, making a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check with the DC based on the distance and speed, in order to do so successfully.

entries.name: Crashes & Wiping Out
entries: When a vehicle wipes out or crashes, the vehicle and all passengers take substantial damage.

When a vehicle wipes out, it takes bludgeoning damage equal to a roll of half of its total hit dice (rounded down) + its Constitution modifier, as does each creature in the vehicle unless they succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, in which case they instead take half damage.

When a vehicle crashes, all of the above is the same, except the damage equals a roll of all of the vehicles total hit dice + its Constitution modifier, and the damage type changes to force for both the vehicle and the creatures inside, as the Infernal Engine of the vehicle explodes.

entries.name: Vehicle Properties
entries: Vehicles use stat blocks, much like monsters. Here is a rundown of what everything means.

entries.name: Stats
entries: When fighting while in a vehicle, or fighting a creature on a vehicle, attack rolls are made with disadvantage and creatures have advantage on saving throws against any creature not moving at similar speed. If multiple vehicles are moving next to each other at a similar speed, the creatures in them act in combat as normal, as if they were not moving at all.

items.name: Seats
items.entry: Indicates the number of total passengers a vehicle can comfortably hold, including the driver.

items.name: Hit Points
items.entry: Indicates a car's health. When it drops to 0, the vehicle is destroyed. Vehicles cannot spend hit dice to recover their hit points, they must instead be repaired using {@item Runetech Tools|ccg}.

items.name: Ability Scores
items.entry: The stat blocks for vehicles don't include Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma. All vehicles have 0 in these stats and automatically fail any ability checks or saving throws that use these scores.

entries.name: Speed
entries: A vehicle indicates a speed in its stat block. This indicates the usual maximum speed it can move each turn, though it takes at least two rounds of movement for a vehicle to reach that speed. Here is a list of usual speeds for land vehicles per turn, depending on the environment:
{@b Slow (Tight Spaces).} 30 feet (3.5 mph)
{@b Average (Narrow Streets).} 300 feet (35 mph)
{@b Fast (Highways).} 500 feet (60 mph)
{@b Very Fast (Chase).} 700 feet (80 mph)
{@b Breakneck (Ludicrous).} 950 feet+ (100 mph+)

entries.name: Speed Isn't Everything
entries: When two vehicles are in a race or in a pursuit, you should consider not only those vehicles' max speed, but the environment they are driving through. If they have to take many sharp turns or perform maneuvers through traffic, having a better driver is often much more valuable than having faster car.

entries.name: Vehicle Upgrades
entries: Vehicles can be upgraded with a variety of additional parts that augment their properties. These upgrades are split into two categories—body upgrades and weapon upgrades, which can be found in the tables below. A vehicle can't have more total body or total weapon upgrades than it has seats. Each body upgrade can only be chosen once.

entries.name: Using Weapon Upgrades
entries: Vehicle weapons can be operated by passengers in the vehicle, as long as they have proficiency in martial weapons. The provided vehicle weapons detail a specific weapon attack, and this attack can be made as an action, requiring the user to use both of their hands. Vehicle weapons use the operating character's Strength or Dexterity score (based on the weapon) as well as their proficiency bonus (PB) in their attack and damage rolls. If a character can make multiple attacks as a part of the attack action on their turn, they can make that many attacks when they use their action to attack with a vehicle weapon.

rows: {@b Arcane Camouflage.} The vehicle has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide.
{@b Arcane Cushion Field.} Passengers take half the amount of damage they would normally when {@variantrule Crashes & Wiping Out|ccg|wiping out or crashing}.
{@b Engine Upgrade.} The vehicle's speed increases by 100 feet for every 2000 gp spent, up to a maximum ground speed of 1900 feet (200 mph) or a maximum flying speed of 1000 ft (115 mph).
{@b Extra Seat.} You add one extra seat to the vehicle, altering the chassis to do so.
{@b Flight.} It gains a flying speed equal to half of its max speed, and can hover while flying this way.
{@b Hook Cannon.} As a maneuver, the driver can fire steel grappling hook from the front of a vehicle. If it hits another vehicle, it becomes tethered. The wire has an AC of 19 and 20 hit points.
{@b Mana Booster.} A passenger can expend a spell slot to increase the vehicle's max speed for the next 10 minutes. This speed increase equals 90 feet (10 mph) times the level of the slot expended.
{@b Spiked Bumper and Wheels.} When damaging another vehicle using a maneuver, you roll twice as many dice as you would usually, and the damage type changes to piercing.
{@b Tank.} The vehicle's maximum hit points and total hit dice are doubled, and it gains +1 AC.

{@b Window Shielding.} Creatures inside the vehicle have {@quickref Cover||3||total cover} from effects outside. This trait doesn't function while the car is below half its maximum hit points, and vehicle weapons can't be used while the windows are up.
{@b {@item Runetech Railgun|ccg}.} (Ranged, 120/480 ft). Dexterity + PB to hit. | 1d12 + Dexterity piercing.
{@b {@item Flame Mortar|ccg}.} (Ranged, 30/120 ft). Strength + PB to hit. | 1d8 + Strength fire. Also, it has the burst (1d6) property and deals double damage to objects and structures.
{@b {@item Arcatech Chaingun|ccg}.} (Ranged, 80/320 ft). Strength + PB to hit. | 1d4 + Strength force. Once per turn when you would make a single attack with this weapon, make two instead.
{@b {@item Devastator|ccg}.} (Ranged, 80/320 ft). Dexterity + PB to hit. | 2d6 + Dexterity force. Also, it has the pierce (1d12) property.

variantrule.name: Crashes & Wiping Out
entries: {@note The below is taken from {@variantrule Vehicles in Crystalpunk|ccg} for quick reference.}
