When a vehicle wipes out or crashes, the vehicle and all passengers take substantial damage.

When a vehicle wipes out, it takes bludgeoning damage equal to a roll of half of its total hit dice (rounded down) + its Constitution modifier, as does each creature in the vehicle unless they succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, in which case they instead take half damage.

When a vehicle crashes, all of the above is the same, except the damage equals a roll of all of the vehicles total hit dice + its Constitution modifier, and the damage type changes to force for both the vehicle and the creatures inside, as the Infernal Engine of the vehicle explodes.

variantrule.name: Using Weapon Upgrades
entries: {@note The below is taken from {@variantrule Vehicles in Crystalpunk|ccg} for quick reference.}

Vehicle weapons can be operated by passengers in the vehicle, as long as they have proficiency in martial weapons. The provided vehicle weapons detail a specific weapon attack, and this attack can be made as an action, requiring the user to use both of their hands. Vehicle weapons use the operating character's Strength or Dexterity score (based on the weapon) as well as their proficiency bonus (PB) in their attack and damage rolls. If a character can make multiple attacks as a part of the attack action on their turn, they can make that many attacks when they use their action to attack with a vehicle weapon.

variantrule.name: Integrated Items
entries: Some {@filter Upgrades|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=EU} from the {@filter Arm Augmentation|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=EA|hash=arm augmentation_ccg} allow you to integrate items into your arms. While integrated, you can retract and extend the item at will (no action required), unless the item is a shield, in which case it takes an action. You still have a hand, but it is not considered free while these items are extended. If the item is a weapon with the twohanded property, you must still use your other hand to make an attack with it. Lastly, you can only have one integrated item in each arm.

variantrule.name: Potent Focus
entries: When a spellcaster wields their spellcasting focus in two hands, your GM can rule that its grant them a 50% range increase on spells they cast through it, up to a maximum of a 30 feet increase. This should not apply to spells with a range of Self or Touch.

entries.name: Vehicle Weapon
entries: Vehicle weapons can be operated by passengers in the vehicle, as long as they have proficiency in martial weapons. The provided vehicle weapons detail a specific weapon attack, and this attack can be made as an action, requiring the user to use both of their hands. Vehicle weapons use the operating character's Strength or Dexterity score (based on the weapon) as well as their proficiency bonus in their attack and damage rolls. If a character can make multiple attacks as a part of the attack action on their turn, they can make that many attacks when they use their action to attack with a vehicle weapon.

itemType.name: regular gear pack
entries: {@note See {@item Regular Gear Pack|ccg} for more information about gear packs.}

itemType.name: tool gear pack
entries: {@note See {@item Tool Gear Pack|ccg} for more information about gear packs.}

entries.name: Medium Armor Improvement
entries: Once a character reaches 5th level, the base AC of medium armor increases by 1, representing your character's increased proficiency in them. The maximum bonus to AC from Dexterity remains +2.

entries.name: Heavy Armor Improvement
entries: Once a character reaches 5th level, the base AC of heavy armor increases by 2, representing your character's increased proficiency in them. The maximum bonus to AC from Strength remains +3.

entries.name: Spread
entries: When taking the attack action with a spread weapon, you can make a special attack that hits multiple creatures. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the attack action, this attack replaces one of them. When you make this special attack, you can force all creatures within a specific area to make a Dexterity saving throw:

entries.name: Spread weapon save
entries.text: 8 + your normal attack roll modifier for the weapon

entries: On a failed save, a creature takes the damage listed in the parentheses next to the property, plus your ability modifier. You also add any other static damage bonuses that apply to your weapon's damage roll, such as from rage, a fighting style, or a +1 weapon (but not any extra dice).

When a creature fails their saving throw against one of your spread attacks, it counts as a successful hit for features and items (but not spells) that trigger on a hit weapon attack. When you use such effects, apply them to all targets that failed their saving throw and that would have been eligible if you had hit a normal attack with the weapon against them. If the feature or item adds extra damage in the form of dice—such as {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1}, {@classFeature Divine Smite|Paladin||2}, or the {@class fighter||Weaponforger's|Weaponforger|ccg} {@filter Weapon Mods|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=WM}, roll one less damage dice than usual when triggering those features this way (a minimum of one extra die).

entries.name: Burst
entries: The spread weapon area for a burst weapon is a 10-foot cube originating from a target location within the weapon's normal range.

entries.name: Pierce
entries: The spread weapon area for a pierce weapon is a 1-foot wide line towards a target location within the weapon's normal range.

entries.name: Erupt
entries: The spread weapon area for an erupt weapon is a 15-foot cone originating from the weapon in a direction of your choice.

entries.name: Cleave
entries: The spread weapon area for a cleave weapon is a 10-foot-radius circle centered on you.

entries.name: Siege
entries: This weapon deals double damage to objects and structures.

entries.name: Arcanic
entries: Arcanic weapons fire bolts of arcane energy without expending ammunition, instead drawing some mana from the user and expelling it as a powerful arcane blast. You can use a weapon that has the arcanic property to make a ranged attack, using the range in parentheses after the property. Despite their magical nature, arcanic weapons do not bypass resistance or immunity to nonmagical damage, unless they are a magical weapon.

entries.name: Close-quarters
entries: When making a ranged attack with a close-quarters weapon against a target within 5 feet, you don't suffer disadvantage on the attack roll as a result of being in close combat.

entries.name: Defender
entries: Weapons with the defender property also count as shields, though they only grant a +1 bonus to AC. You can benefit from only one weapon with the defender property or one shield at a time. Making an attack with any weapon that lacks the defender property changes your stance, preventing you from gaining the AC bonus of a defender weapon until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Minimum Strength Requirement (11)
entries: This weapon requires a Strength score of 11 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Dexterity Requirement (11)
entries: This weapon requires a Dexterity score of 11 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Intelligence Requirement (11)
entries: This weapon requires an Intelligence score of 11 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Wisdom Requirement (11)
entries: This weapon requires a Wisdom score of 11 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Charisma Requirement (11)
entries: This weapon requires a Charisma score of 11 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Strength Requirement (13)
entries: This weapon requires a Strength score of 13 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Dexterity Requirement (13)
entries: This weapon requires a Dexterity score of 13 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

entries.name: Minimum Intelligence Requirement (13)
entries: This weapon requires a Intelligence score of 13 or higher to wield effectively. A creature attacking with this weapon that does not meet the requirement makes the attack with disadvantage, and if the weapon has the Spread property, they cannot use its special attack.

item.name: Alchemist's Supplies
entries: Items fit for an alchemist, which could include beakers, stirring rods, and alchemical ingredients.

item.name: Armorer's Supplies
entries: Equipment for crafting and repairing armor, which could include {@item hammer|phb|hammers}, tongs, and spare sheets of metal.

item.name: Artist's Tools
entries: Equipment fit for an artist, which could include a sketchbook, brushes, writing equipment, and cans of spray paint.

item.name: Chemist's Tools
entries: A set of items for creating narcotics, which could include glass flasks, solvents, and containers.

item.name: Runetech Tools
entries: Equipment fit for a magitech engineer, which could include carving tools, crystals, and spare bottles of mana.

item.name: Tinker's Tools
entries: Equipment fit for repairs and tinkering, which could include a variety of hand tools, spare screws, small metal parts, and a {@item whetstone|phb}.

item.name: Cosmetics Kit
entries: A set of items to prepare yourself for the stage, which could include makeup, a hand mirror, and {@item perfume (vial)|phb|perfume}.

item.name: Disguise Kit
entries: A set of items to change your appearance entirely, which could include a wig, glasses, a mask, and pieces of clothing.

item.name: Performer's Kit
entries: Items fit for a musical performance, which includes a {@filter musical instrument|items|type=instrument}, and also could include an arcanic amplifier and a set of trendy clothes.
Proficiency in at least one musical instrument grants you proficiency in the performer's kit.

item.name: Poisoner's Kit
entries: A set of items for creating poisons, which could include {@item vial|phb|glass vials}, dangerous chemicals, foul ingredients, and stirring rods.

item.name: Thieves' Tools
entries: A set of items fit for a thief, which could include gloves, lock picks, pliers, and scissors.

item.name: Vehicles (Land, Water, or Air)
entries: Proficiency in one of these vehicle 'gear packs' allows you to better drive vehicles of the chosen type.

item.name: Casual Gear
entries: A set of items used in your day to day life, which could include an {@item arcane watch|ccg}, a crystal flashlight, clothes, and an umbrella.

item.name: Demolition Gear
entries: Items fit for demolition, which could include a {@item crowbar|phb}, a {@item sledgehammer|phb}, tiny magical explosives, and a set of pliers.

item.name: Enforcement Gear
entries: Items fit for an enforcer, which could include handcuffs, a gas mask, a helmet, and a battering ram.

item.name: Gambling Gear
entries: Items fit for a gambler, which could include {@item dice set|phb|sets of dice}, playing cards, and game tokens.

item.name: Investigation Gear
entries: Items fit for an investigation, which could include gloves, a {@item magnifying glass|phb}, and measuring equipment.

item.name: Medical Gear
entries: Items fit for tending wounds, which could include bandages, stitches, needles, salves, and splints. If you have medical gear, you have advantage on any Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) checks made to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points.

item.name: Mining Gear
entries: Items fit for a miner, which could include an arcane pickaxe, a {@item shovel|phb}, a {@item hammer|phb}, and a duster.

item.name: Pathfinding Gear
entries: Items fit for a scout, which could include {@item Hempen Rope (50 feet)|phb|rope}, a {@item grappling hook|phb}, binoculars, and other tools for climbing.

item.name: Prayer Gear
entries: Items used in prayers and rituals, which could include an amulet, a {@item reliquary|phb}, {@item candle|phb|candles}, and a prayer book.

item.name: Survival Gear
entries: Items fit for surviving in the wilderness, which could include {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, a water bottle, a {@item bedroll|phb}, {@item hunting trap|phb|hunting traps}, and a {@item mess kit|phb}.

item.name: Arcane Watch
entries: This wrist-mounted device enables the wearer to know what time of day it is at all times.

entries.name: Arcane Artillery
entries: {@class sorcerer||Sorcerers}, {@class warlock||Warlocks}, and {@class wizard||Wizards} gain access to two firearm style spellcasting focuses, the Channeling Pistol and the {@item Channeling Rifle|ccg}. These are often used to sling spells in the style of shooting with firearms. Here are some examples of spells that work well with this flavor of casting.
{@b Blasts:} {@spell Fire Bolt}, {@spell Eldritch Blast}, {@spell Ray of Frost}
{@b Bursts:} {@spell Thunderwave}, {@spell Fireball}, {@spell Lightning Bolt}
{@b Rapid-Fire:} {@spell Magic Missile}, {@spell Scorching Ray}

entries.name: Arcane Artillery
entries: {@class sorcerer||Sorcerers}, {@class warlock||Warlocks}, and {@class wizard||Wizards} gain access to two firearm style spellcasting focuses, the {@item Channeling Pistol|ccg} and the Channeling Rifle. These are often used to sling spells in the style of shooting with firearms. Here are some examples of spells that work well with this flavor of casting.
{@b Blasts:} {@spell Fire Bolt}, {@spell Eldritch Blast}, {@spell Ray of Frost}
{@b Bursts:} {@spell Thunderwave}, {@spell Fireball}, {@spell Lightning Bolt}
{@b Rapid-Fire:} {@spell Magic Missile}, {@spell Scorching Ray}

item.name: Runic Symbol (on clothes or on a shield)

entries.name: Chaingun
entries: Once per turn when you would make a single attack with this weapon, make two instead.

entries.name: Special
entries: You have disadvantage when you use this weapon to attack a target within 5 feet of you. While you are mounted, this weapon only requires one hand to wield and it gains the pierce ({@damage 1d10}) property.

entries.name: Special
entries: You cannot make an attack with this weapon while wielding a shield. If your other hand is free while wielding this weapon, it gains the defender property.

item.name: Arcane Narcotic (uncommon)
entries: While many mundane narcotics exist in Aysta, arcane narcotics hold immense magical power. This magically created narcotic comes in a variety of different types. Each has a number of properties and side effects, which can be determined by choosing from the tables below or by rolling on those tables to determine the results randomly. The narcotic has the same amount of properties and side effects, and the amount of each is determined by its rarity (Uncommon: 1, {@item Arcane Narcotic (rare)|ccg|Rare}: 2, {@item Arcane Narcotic (very rare)|ccg|Very Rare}: 3). Properties and side effects can only be selected more than once if one says so in its description.

A character can use their action to ingest the narcotic, gaining the benefits of its properties and suffering its side effects. The {@spell lesser restoration} spell can be used to cure the effects of all noninstantaneous side effects that the narcotic induces.

If a character uses the same arcane narcotic often, the GM can rule that they develop an {@condition addicted|ccg|addiction}. A character with such an addiction has two permanent levels of exhaustion. Ingesting the narcotic removes these exhaustion levels until the addicted character finishes their next long rest.

entries.caption: Narcotic Properties
rows: {@b Adrenaline.} You have advantage on Athletics and Acrobatics checks for 1 hour.
{@b Agility.} You gain a +1 bonus to AC and have advantage on initiative rolls for 8 hours.
{@b Awareness.} You have advantage on {@skill Perception}, {@skill Insight}, and {@skill Investigation} checks for 1 hour.
{@b Confidence.} You have advantage on all Charisma checks for 1 hour.
{@b Healing.} You regain {@dice 3d12} hit points. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Infusion.} You regain one expended spell slot of 3rd-level or lower. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Numbness.} You have advantage on Constitution saving throws for 8 hours.

{@b Potency.} Roll 2d6 to determine two random ability scores, re-rolling duplicates. Choose one of the results, which becomes 19 for you for the next 8 hours if that score of yours is not already 19 or higher.
{@b Swiftness.} Your walking speed is increased by 30 feet for 1 hour.
{@b Visions.} For the next 8 hours, you can cast the {@spell augury} and {@spell see invisibility} spells at will.

entries.caption: Narcotic Side Effects
rows: {@b Shaky.} For the next hour, whenever you make a saving throw that you don't have advantage on, you must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the result.
{@b Fatigued.} For the next hour, whenever you make an ability check that you don't have advantage on, you must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the result.
{@b Scorched.} You take {@damage 1d12} necrotic damage, which can't be reduced in any way. Can be selected multiple times.
{@b Lethargic.} You have disadvantage on Initiative rolls for the next 8 hours.
{@b Loud.} You have disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks for the next hour.
{@b Sluggish.} Your walking speed is decreased by 10 feet for the next hour.

itemGroup.name: Tool Gear Pack
entries: All items other than weapons, armor, spellcasting focuses and magic items are now categorized under gear packs. These gear packs are a set of items that all pertain to a specific purpose. The exact contents of each pack is not absolute—if you think it should contain an item and your GM agrees, the pack contains that item. As such, most items which your character carries are abstracted, and specific amounts of these items are not tracked.

A character can carry a maximum of two gear packs on their person at a time. If a character has a Strength Score of 13 or higher, they can carry three gear packs at a time instead. {@item Casual Gear|ccg} does not count towards the maximum number of gear packs a character can carry.

Some of these gear packs are also tools, which abide by their normal rules in addition to being a gear pack and having its properties. A character can only make a skill check and have the option to be proficient with these types of gear packs.
Lastly, feel free to come up with custom gear packs if they would better fit your character. Discuss with your GM to determine what it could include.

entries.name: Why Use Packs?
entries: Crystalpunk uses gear packs to simplify and abstract mundane equipment, as gritty resource tracking isn't a focus of Crystalpunk games. Also, most mundane items can be very easily be acquired from vendors within the city, making tracking them a bit trivial.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: While the cycle is moving and the cycle or any of its riders are subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, a target instead take no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage it fails.

trait.name: Stunts
entries: When performing a maneuver with the cycle that relies on the cycle's speed, such as a jump or wheelie, the driver makes the Dexterity check with advantage.

trait.name: Unprotected
entries: If you {@variantrule Crashes & Wiping Out|ccg|wipe out or crash} on an Arcane Cycle, you take triple the normal damage.

trait.name: Infernal Engine

items: A muted creature cannot speak or willingly make sound.
A muted creature cannot cast spells with verbal components (unless otherwise allowed to ignore verbal components, such as through a spell or feature).
A dazed creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws.
A creature addicted to an arcane narcotic has two permanent levels of {@condition exhaustion}.
These levels of exhaustion are removed if the creature ingests the narcotic they are addicted to, until the end of their next long rest.

entries.name: Evolutionist

entries: Every living creature brought into this world is a seed, bursting with potential, yet somehow only the truly ambitious are willing to destroy themselves in order to grow into a tree.

A dwarf stares into a mirror, carefully slotting a glowing crystalline object into the cavity where his eye once was. A sudden click echoes throughout his workshop as the device springs to life. He blinks and gazes around the room, testing his new optical equipment. After a short moment, he places his tools back on the desk in front of him, next to his knife and his recently severed eyeball.

A half-elven woman covered from head to toe in black robes is confronted by a group of thugs in an alleyway. As they make their demands, she stares at the ground, refusing to make eye contact with them. One of the thugs draws a knife, but before he can take a single step he is abruptly lifted high into the air. The others look on in horror as monstrous tentacles lash out from the woman, grasping him by the throat.

Sweat drips from a halfling's chin as he kneels within a circle of blood, nightmarish monsters closing in on all sides. His breath quickens as he unsteadily lifts a blade to his shoulder. With one swift motion, he closes his eyes and tears through his upper arm, cleaving it straight from his body. The halfling's screams echo throughout the cold stone chamber as bones and flesh rapidly erupt from his shoulder, forming a horrendous new limb. In an instant, the pain on his face gives way to a maniacal grin as he stands up, letting loose with his new modification.

entries.name: What Is an Evolutionist?
entries: Evolutionists are ambitious warriors; who rather than building their strength through practice and training, improve their natural talents by enhancing and upgrading their body. They reject the idea that they should play the hand they're dealt, instead seeking to change the game. Where most accept the body they are given, evolutionists aim to control it and push it past its limits. Each evolutionist has different methods and motivations for upgrading their body, but they all are connected by one common goal: evolution.

entries.name: Continual Improvement
entries: Evolutionists are defined by their yearning to improve their bodies through methods that go beyond mere training. They achieve this through a variety of means, from inventive technology and alchemy to ancient magics or even pacts with otherworldly beings. No matter the method, an evolutionist begins to change and alter their form by augmenting their body or growing completely new appendages. These upgrades allow evolutionists to overpower their enemies, either through raw enhanced capability or through unique tactics enabled by their non-standard biology. Evolutionists live a life of continual growth, utilizing the abilities they gain to seek methods to enhance their bodies even further.

entries.name: Paradoxical Identities
entries: An evolutionist's body is the foundation of their identity, the ultimate focus of their efforts. For them, the body is the most fundamental, intrinsic expression of identity and purpose—from an elk's antlers to a bat's ears, every biological adaptation has an explicit reason for existing. Evolutionists often chase after their personal concept of a perfected body, often driven by perceptions of physical weakness, mental ineptitude, or visual unattractiveness. The pursuit of perfection is not without its risks, however. Paradoxically, these same individuals who see the body as a form of expression have a tendency to dissociate from it as they stack up modifications. Some come to perceive the body as little more than a tool or vehicle operated by the brain or soul. While this mentality may facilitate even greater upgrades, it begs an uneasy question; where does the person end and the enhancements begin?

entries.name: Ambitious Sacrifices
entries: Sacrifice is central to the evolutionist's work. They must forfeit parts of themselves—one day, removing a leg to replace it with an upgraded prosthetic; the next, altering their appearance to suit a new enhancement. While these physically orientated modifications give them the capability to fight toe to toe with the best of martial combatants, evolutionists have greater ambitions. They push their enhancements further than their body can handle, tearing into their own vitality. Endurance is the most important quality for an evolutionist; the ability to suffer through their ambition is paramount to their success. They stop at nothing in pursuit of their goals; even despite the risk of harm to themselves. Sometimes, they make their greatest sacrifices without even realizing it.

entries.name: Freakish Forms
entries: As a result of their work, evolutionists almost always look strange. Modifications to their body rarely go unnoticed, often making people wary of them. Opinions regarding individual evolutionists vary drastically, from disgust and fear to respect and admiration. They are often treated differently not just for their appearance, but also the implications it has for their mental state—surely no one who would do that to themselves is right in their head. Dealing with such reactions on a daily basis, evolutionists tend to be able to overcome others' opinions of them with relative ease. Some evolutionists are timid and self-conscious, trying to blend in and cowering at hostility. Others relish the notoriety, happily claiming the spotlight—even negative attention is attention. The most dangerous tolerate no hints of judgment, potentially flying into a murderous frenzy at the slightest side-eye.

entries.name: Creating an Evolutionist
entries: As you create your evolutionist character, you should consider exactly how your character upgrades their body. As a starting character, you'll choose a method that defines the general nature of your enhancements, but the exact form of your upgrades is up to you. Do you enhance your current body? Or do you remove and replace parts of your body? Is your character methodical and careful when upgrading their body, or do they make changes as crudely and quickly as possible? Your choice in how your character changes their body is integral to their appearance as well as how others treat them. Each upgrade your character attains will change who they are, and it is this progression of changes that defines you as an evolutionist.

Secondly, you should consider why your character decided to follow this controversial and dangerous path. Was it simply a lust for power, or do they have a larger goal? Each evolutionist has a reason for why they continually improve themselves, due to the sacrifices that come with it. Does your character strive to overcome some obstacle? Or is there something your character wishes to change about themselves? Furthermore, you should consider how your character was led to enhancing their body. Were they introduced to the practice by another, or did it begin with a major chaotic event? Did your character choose this path, or was it thrust upon them? Having a clear idea of your character's goals and origins will help you inform your decisions further down the line.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make an evolutionist quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Constitution your highest score, followed by Strength or Dexterity, based on how you want to fight. Second, choose the {@background Mercenary|ccg} background.

entries.name: Soulshaper

entries: I don't know where this power came from, I don't know what it even is, and I don't know why it chose me. What I do know is that it has given me a second chance, and I intend to use it.

A robed nephilim kneels in a forest clearing watching her young students enjoying a break from their lessons. A sudden cry of fear sounds from the woods nearby, and the nephilim moves swiftly to find a nightmarish creature attacking a student. She cries out, the magical manifestation of the grief from a former pupil she couldn't save pulsing around her. This spectral wave closes the student's wounds, and obliterates the nightmare.

A half-elven charlatan realizes that the jig is up and his scam has failed. The mob that he has tried to garner sympathy and donations from has turned against him, and they close in on him while he is apparently unarmed. With a wave of his hand, he summons a brilliantly glowing purple blade, intricately detailed. He wards the angry crowd away with the weapon before leaping onto his spectral horse, riding quickly toward the next town he can try his act on.

A curseborn Psychopomp kneels over the corpse of a thug in an alley, extracting the recently deceased man's soul to place in a battery. A rival Psychopomp spots her, and tries to intervene and claim the soul for himself. Before he can reach her, the curseborn raises an arm, and the man is stunned in place. As the curseborn's soul holds him, she begins incanting a spell, and all the Psychopomp can do is watch his obliteration come.

entries.name: What Is a Soulshaper?
entries: Soulshapers are mystical spiritualists who can effortlessly manipulate the spectral energy of their soul and the souls of others. Their powers are awakened by a moment of sudden enlightenment, rarely found through meditation but more commonly realized through a near-death experience. Their powers continue to develop based on the emotion that revealed them, from serene acceptance to a furious desire for revenge.

entries.name: Bridges to the Beyond
entries: Soulshapers can see the souls of the living and the dead, and can physically manipulate them. They are mediums between life and death, and between the Ethereal and Material Planes. Soulshapers use their powers for different purposes; some use their ability to physically manipulate souls to become Psychopomps or work with Soul Batteries, while others use their intimate knowledge of emotions to become negotiators, counselors or politicians. Some soulshapers who awaken their potential on the streets will use their powers nefariously, becoming thieves or scam artists with their abilities complimenting their natural talents.

entries.name: Awakened Potential
entries: The moment of awakening is different for every soulshaper, but it is always a moment of intense emotion. For some, this is a moment of acceptance; a resignation to their death before being saved by an outside source. Soulshapers who awaken this way feel a sense of calm each time they channel their powers—after all, each moment they are alive is a bonus, and every effect they can have is one they may not have had otherwise. For others, it is a moment of pure terror, where they will do anything in their power to survive and their soul responds. These soulshapers channel their powers on pure adrenaline and instinct, recalling the moment when they brushed with death. Others still are so overcome with rage that they begin using their powers before they even realize what they are capable of. Their pure desire for revenge for whatever reason drives the use of their powers, and every time they channel their abilities, they return to that blood-boiling moment of fury.

entries.name: Inner Focus
entries: Awakening one's power is the easy part. Soulshapers draw their power directly from within themselves, and rigorous meditation is needed to hone their connection to their soul and the world around them. The meditative practices of a soulshaper varies based on their discipline, and this meditation allows them to not only enhance their powers, but develop new ones. A soulshaper can never improve without taking the time to focus inwards.

entries.name: Creating a Soulshaper
entries: When creating a soulshaper, you should first consider an event that caused your character to awaken their powers. Was it a terrible crime they witnessed? A grievous injury they survived? An acceptance of their fate before they were saved? Your decision will affect not only how your character harnesses their powers, but also how they act both in and out of combat. Soulshapers are defined by emotion, and it is important to consider the emotional aspect you wish to focus on.

Next, decide on what your character uses this newfound power for. Do they use their abilities to help others, or do they use them selfishly? Do they flaunt their powers or hide them? Have they sought a teacher to learn their powers, or do they experiment alone? Consider these questions when shaping the history of your character, as they will provide a foundation for decisions later on, both in character creation and in game.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a soulshaper quickly by following these suggestions. First, Wisdom should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution. Second, choose the {@background Shaman|ccg} background. Third, choose the {@spell thaumaturgy} and {@spell eldritch blast} cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells {@spell command}, {@spell cure wounds}, and {@spell guiding bolt}.
